Description: A small freshwater fish native to South America, known for its unique breeding behavior. The female lays eggs on overhanging leaves, and the male keeps them moist by splashing water with his tail until they hatch. Usually grows up to 6 cm and is peaceful, making it popular in aquariums.

A schooling fish from the Amazon Basin with a translucent yellow body and bright lemon-colored fins. It grows up to 5 cm and prefers to live in groups. Hardy and peaceful, it adds vivid color to community aquariums.
A small cyprinid fish native to India and Bangladesh. It has a bright golden body, usually reaching 5 cm in length. Active and schooling in nature, it is hardy and commonly kept in aquariums.

Found in South America, this tetra is named for its glowing spots near the head and tail. Growing up to 5 cm, it is peaceful and thrives in schools. Its “headlight and taillight” markings make it a favorite in community tanks.

A striped freshwater fish from South Asia, widely used in research due to its transparent embryos and genetic similarities to humans. It grows up to 5 cm, is hardy, and thrives in groups. Active and easy to keep in aquariums.

A larger danio species found in rivers of South and Southeast Asia. It can grow up to 10-15 cm and has blue and gold horizontal stripes. Strong swimmers and very active, they are best kept in groups in large aquariums.

Native to Southeast Asia, this slender barb is recognized by its shiny metallic scales and long barbels extending past its pectoral fins. It grows to about 6–7 cm and is fast-moving, often seen darting across aquariums.

A bottom-dwelling fish found in Europe, with a slender body covered in mottled patterns. It grows up to 12 cm and has small spines under the eyes used as a defense. Known for burrowing into sand and being active at night.

A small invasive cyprinid from East Asia, now widespread in Europe. Silver-gray with a dark lateral stripe, it grows up to 10 cm. Highly adaptable and reproduces rapidly, often outcompeting native fish.

A peaceful armored catfish from South America, growing up to 7 cm. It has mottled gray and black patterns resembling “pepper.” A bottom-dweller that scavenges for food, usually kept in groups in aquariums.
A livebearing fish from South America, usually 4-6 cm long. It tolerates a wide range of salinities and feeds on mosquito larvae, making it useful in mosquito control.
Endemic to Lake Pátzcuaro, Mexico. Slender, silvery body reaching 20 cm. Economically important as food fish but threatened by habitat degradation.
Small freshwater fish with a transparent body, native to South Asia. Grows up to 8 cm and is popular in aquariums.
A small, fast-swimming cyprinid with iridescent pinkish-blue scales. Native to Southeast Asia, grows up to 6 cm, peaceful and hardy.
A small cyprinid fish (4-6 cm) from East Asia. Known for laying eggs inside freshwater mussels, where embryos develop safely.
Native to Southeast Asia, this fish grows up to 7 cm. Wild form is olive-green with stripes, while the aquarium strain is bright golden.
A hardy freshwater fish capable of breathing air and moving short distances on land. Native to South and Southeast Asia, reaching 25 cm.
A small goby (up to 10 cm) found in East Asian rivers and streams. Benthic and insectivorous, often used in local fisheries.
Found in North America, inhabiting slow waters with muddy bottoms. Grows to 13 cm, known for tolerance to low oxygen levels.
A small bagrid catfish from South Asia, growing up to 12 cm. Identified by its dark body with pale spots; omnivorous and hardy.
A pelagic schooling fish found in the Mediterranean and Atlantic. Grows to 20 cm, commercially important as food and bait.
Native to the Amazon Basin, with tall, triangular fins and laterally compressed body. Popular ornamental fish, reaching 15 cm.
Endemic to Lake Sentani, Papua. Males develop bright red coloration, growing up to 15 cm. Popular in aquariums.
A small cyprinid native to South Asia, found in rivers and streams. Slender, silvery body reaching 10 cm.
A small herring-like fish from the Black and Caspian Seas. Forms large schools, feeding on plankton, reaching 10–12 cm.
Native to rivers of India and Bangladesh, reaching 10 cm. Strong swimmer with horizontal stripes.
Popular aquarium fish from South Asia, usually 6-10 cm. Males show bright red during breeding, while females are golden.
Endemic to Turkey’s Sakarya River basin. Small, silvery fish up to 12 cm, often found in schools.
A hardy cichlid from South America, reaching 15 cm. Known for changing coloration depending on mood and breeding.
Brackish-water fish with a diamond-shaped silvery body. Native to Indo-Pacific estuaries, grows up to 25 cm.
An elongated freshwater loach from East Asia, reaching 25 cm. Hardy, burrows in mud, and used in traditional medicine.
A predatory Asian fish with a compressed body and mottled coloration for camouflage. Reaches up to 20 cm.
A small cyprinid (up to 7 cm) from East Asia. Females lay eggs in freshwater mussels, a unique reproductive adaptation.
Native to India and Sri Lanka. Slender body with horizontal stripes, reaching 8 cm. Prefers streams and rivers.
A South Indian barb up to 15 cm. Males develop long filamentous extensions on dorsal fins during breeding.
Freshwater loach native to China, reaching 18 cm. Burrows in soft substrates and feeds on benthic invertebrates.
A South American cichlid, up to 25 cm. Sifts sand through its mouth to feed, hence the name “eartheater.”
A slender eel-like fish with banded markings, reaching 15 cm. Found in Southeast Asia, active at night.
A small characin (6-8 cm) from South America with dark vertical stripes. Peaceful schooling species for aquariums.
A small cyprinid from South Asia, usually 5-8 cm long. Found in rivers, streams, and ponds; commonly used as food and bait fish.
A widely distributed goby across Asia and Oceania. Grows up to 50 cm, with a long body and spotted patterns. Important food fish in many regions.
A small cyprinid (up to 15 cm) native to East Asia but invasive in many areas. Recognized by its silvery body and sharp belly keel.
Native to Japan, China, and Korea. Elongated body with silvery sides, growing up to 30 cm. Prefers rivers and lakes.
A small schooling fish (up to 20 cm) native to Europe and Western Asia. Silvery, slender body; important prey species for larger fish.
A South American catfish with bony plates along its body. Grows up to 24 cm and can breathe atmospheric air.
A North American sucker fish inhabiting streams and rivers. Grows to 20 cm, with a flattened snout and sucker mouth for scraping algae.
Native to Brazil, up to 25 cm long. Known for sand-sifting feeding behavior and pearly spots on the body.
A large, fast-growing cyprinid from Southeast Asia, reaching 35 cm. Silvery with red-tipped fins; popular in aquaculture and aquariums.
Endemic to Lake Van, Turkey. Reaches 25 cm, migrates to rivers to spawn. An important local food fish.
South American cichlid, up to 30 cm long. Known for its brown coloration and peaceful temperament compared to other cichlids.
A small, silvery fish (up to 20 cm) from northern Europe. Recognized by its cucumber-like odor when fresh.
A nocturnal armored catfish from South America, reaching 20 cm. Dark body with white longitudinal stripes. Popular in aquariums.
A small pike species from North America, growing up to 30-40 cm. Ambush predator of small fish and insects.
An anadromous lamprey endemic to the Caspian Sea basin. Jawless fish, parasitic in adult stage.
Invasive goby from the Black and Caspian Seas, now widespread in Europe and North America. Grows to 25 cm, highly adaptable.
A North American sunfish with bright orange belly and long opercular flap. Reaches 30 cm; popular among anglers.
Endemic to eastern Australia, inhabiting rivers and estuaries. Grows up to 40 cm, commercially important.
An elongated swamp eel from South Asia, up to 100 cm long. Used as food and in traditional medicine.
A small predatory fish native to East Asia, invasive in Europe. Grows to 25 cm, hardy and tolerant of poor conditions.
A South American characin resembling a coin, reaching 15 cm. Plant-eating and often kept in aquariums.
A cichlid from the Amazon Basin, up to 20 cm. Males have elongated fin filaments and golden coloration.
A North American freshwater fish, silvery with large eyes. Reaches 40 cm, feeds on insects and small fish.
A knifefish from South and Southeast Asia, up to 60 cm long. Recognized by its bronze sheen and undulating anal fin.
A Colombian cichlid reaching 20 cm. Peaceful compared to other cichlids, with silvery-blue coloration.
South Asian air-breathing catfish, growing up to 30 cm. Known for venomous pectoral spines.
Native to South and Southeast Asia, capable of moving short distances on land. Reaches 50 cm and is farmed widely.
Anadromous clupeid from the Black Sea. Reaches 40 cm, migrates upriver to spawn. Important commercial species.
A small Eurasian perch species, usually 10-15 cm. Hardy, invasive in some regions, and feeds on benthic invertebrates.
Native to Japan, reaching 35 cm. A hardy carp species, often found in ponds and rivers.
A South American catfish reaching 25 cm. Nocturnal and secretive, often hiding during the day among submerged wood.
Native to western USA, inhabiting lakes and rivers. Grows up to 45 cm, omnivorous, and serves as prey for larger fish.
A South American cichlid with a round, laterally compressed body. Reaches 25 cm, omnivorous, and popular in aquariums.
Central American cichlid reaching 35 cm. Aggressive and territorial, with variable coloration from white to orange-red.
Native to Borneo and Sumatra, bright orange with black bands. Social fish, reaching 30 cm, popular in aquariums.
An armored catfish from South America, reaching 50 cm. Feeds on algae and detritus; hardy but often outgrows aquariums.
A South American cichlid, up to 20 cm, that sifts sand through its mouth to extract food. Peaceful and social.
A North American catfish up to 60 cm. Recognized by its yellow belly and barbels, omnivorous and hardy.
A South American armored catfish with sail-like dorsal fin, reaching 40 cm. Invasive in many countries due to aquarium releases.
A spiny eel from South and Southeast Asia, up to 90 cm. Elongated with zig-zag markings, nocturnal and burrowing.
A small whitefish (15-25 cm) found in northern Europe’s lakes. Planktivorous and important for fisheries.
A North American cyprinid up to 30 cm. Golden sheen, common bait fish, and tolerant of varied habitats.
South American piranha with silvery body and red belly. Reaches 35 cm, known for sharp teeth and schooling behavior.
A Southeast Asian cyprinid up to 25 cm, silvery body with yellow fins. Found in rivers, used as food fish.
Native to Africa and the Middle East, up to 28 cm. Important aquaculture species, mouthbrooding cichlid.
North American sunfish, brightly colored with orange spots and red opercular flap. Grows to 25 cm. Invasive in Europe.
North American sunfish, up to 40 cm, with black speckles. Popular sport fish found in lakes and rivers.
A European cyprinid up to 30 cm, silvery body, found in rivers and streams. Used as bait fish.
A widespread tilapia species, up to 40 cm. Hardy and invasive, introduced worldwide for aquaculture.
A Eurasian cyprinid up to 55 cm, with laterally compressed body resembling a sabre blade.
A brackish-water fish from the Indo-Pacific, reaching 38 cm. Rounded body with dark spots, commonly kept in aquariums and used as food fish.
A large freshwater goby from Southeast Asia, reaching 65 cm. Camouflaged with mottled brown pattern, prized as a food fish.
A Eurasian cyprinid up to 35 cm, inhabiting rivers and lakes. Slender, silvery body, forms large schools.
Native to Africa, reaching 45 cm. Recognized by reddish breast during breeding. Herbivorous and important in aquaculture.
Catadromous species from East Asia, reaching 100 cm. Spawn in the Pacific Ocean and migrate to freshwater rivers.
A South American armored catfish, up to 43 cm. Notable for wood-eating habits and striped black-and-white pattern.
A South Asian cyprinid up to 30 cm. Found in rivers and floodplains, important in local fisheries.
Endemic to Lake Victoria, East Africa. Once abundant, now threatened due to competition from Nile tilapia and Nile perch.
A flatfish up to 60 cm, native to European coasts. Inhabits brackish and marine waters, valued as a food fish.
A Eurasian cyprinid up to 55 cm. Deep-bodied with bluish hue, inhabits rivers and large lakes.
Native to Central America, up to 60 cm. Predatory, with spotted “jaguar-like” pattern, aggressive aquarium fish.
A North American sunfish, up to 43 cm. Stocky body with red eyes, inhabits rocky streams and lakes.
Native to North America, up to 50 cm. Elongated snout with sucker mouth, inhabits cold rivers and lakes.
A parasitic, jawless fish from the Atlantic basin. Anadromous, attaches to other fish with toothed suction mouth.
A South American arowana, up to 90 cm. Juveniles are black with yellow markings; prized ornamental fish.
A freshwater whitefish from Siberia, up to 55 cm. Planktivorous and important in commercial fisheries.
Endemic to Spain’s Ebro River basin, up to 80 cm. Omnivorous and important to local fisheries.
A widespread Eurasian cyprinid, up to 45 cm. Silvery body with reddish fins; highly adaptable.
Anadromous whitefish up to 45 cm, distributed across Arctic rivers and coasts. Migrates long distances for spawning.
Coldwater salmonid with a large, colorful dorsal fin. Found across Arctic North America and Asia.
Once widespread in Europe, now considered extinct in the wild. A whitefish with elongated snout.
A Eurasian cyprinid, up to 36 cm. Deep-bodied with silvery color, common in lakes and slow rivers.
A migratory Eurasian cyprinid up to 50 cm. Slender body, spawns in fast-flowing rivers.
A large armored catfish from South America, up to 50 cm. Invasive in many tropical countries.
A widespread African cichlid, up to 60 cm. One of the most important aquaculture fish worldwide.
A silvery Indo-Pacific fish, up to 40 cm. Found in estuaries and rivers, schooling in behavior.
A North American sucker fish, up to 62 cm. Recognized by golden sheen and red tail, inhabiting rivers.
A salmonid from North America and Siberia, up to 50 cm. Found in cold lakes and rivers, benthic feeder.
A freshwater and estuarine fish, up to 50 cm. Introduced widely for aquaculture and sport fishing.
A large catfish from East Asia, reaching 130 cm. Nocturnal predator, important in Asian fisheries.
A South Asian cyprinid, up to 120 cm. Important sport and food fish, inhabiting fast rivers.
Distributed across South America, up to 45 cm. Omnivorous, hardy, and farmed in aquaculture.
A predatory South American fish, up to 65 cm. Ambush predator with sharp teeth.
A North American catfish, up to 45 cm. Hardy and invasive outside its native range.
A Eurasian cyprinid up to 45 cm. Recognized by red fins and golden body; common in lakes and ponds.
A domesticated carp from East Asia, up to 45 cm in the wild. Wide range of ornamental varieties.
A predatory fish from Eastern Europe, up to 45 cm. Related to zander but smaller.
A freshwater-perching fish, up to 65 cm. Found in eastern Australia, important for sport fishing.
A European cyprinid up to 50 cm. Bottom feeder with scraping mouth; found in rivers.
An Australian catfish with eel-like tail, up to 90 cm. Native to rivers and lakes, important in Aboriginal culture.
A predatory cyprinid from California rivers, up to 1 m. Voracious feeder on smaller fish.
An African cichlid, up to 45 cm. Popular sport and food fish, predatory in nature.
A catadromous eel from the Indo-Pacific, reaching 120 cm. Important in fisheries and aquaculture.
Endemic to Lake Constance, Central Europe. Reaches 60 cm; commercially important.
A predatory fish from South and Southeast Asia, up to 1 m. Air-breathing and invasive in some regions.
A widespread predatory fish in Europe and Asia, up to 60 cm. Recognized by dark vertical bands.
A hardy catfish from North America, up to 35 cm. Introduced to Europe; tolerant of poor water quality.
A Eurasian cyprinid, up to 75 cm. Deep-bodied, silvery-bronze fish common in lakes and rivers.
A South American cichlid, up to 70 cm. Brightly colored predator popular in sport fishing.
Salmonid with a large colorful dorsal fin, up to 60 cm. Found in European cold rivers.
A Eurasian carp species, up to 45 cm. Hardy and invasive, reproduces by gynogenesis.
An Australian freshwater fish, up to 40 cm. Important aquaculture species, omnivorous diet.
A European cyprinid up to 80 cm. Silvery body, kept as ornamental “orfe” in ponds.
A hardy European carp, up to 50 cm. Bronze coloration, tolerates low oxygen waters.
A large freshwater fish from Queensland, up to 90 cm. Shiny scales, prized as ornamental.
A long-snouted predator from southeastern USA, up to 132 cm. Armored scales and sharp teeth.
A tropical Indo-Pacific fish, up to 1 m. Important aquaculture species, especially in the Philippines.
A large Southeast Asian cyprinid, up to 90 cm. Black body, popular but aggressive aquarium fish.
A large predatory goby from the Americas, up to 70 cm. Found in rivers and estuaries.
A South American cichlid, up to 80 cm. Bright blue markings and large size make it a popular sport fish.
The largest cichlid species, endemic to Lake Tanganyika, reaching 90 cm. Predatory and highly valued by local fisheries.
A large freshwater fish from northern Australia, up to 90 cm. Bronze scales with red/orange spots, prized in aquaria.
A North American black bass, up to 64 cm. Found in rivers and lakes; popular sport fish.
Native to California, small salmonid with vivid gold coloration. Coldwater stream species.
Found in East Asia, up to 70 cm. Anadromous, with a prized landlocked form known as yamame.
A primitive North American fish, up to 110 cm. Gular plate and rounded tail are distinctive; voracious predator.
Native to North America, up to 70 cm. Known for bronze body and aggressive sport-fishing behavior.
A large South American predator, up to 120 cm. Jumps to catch prey above water; popular ornamental fish.
A North American sucker fish, up to 55 cm. Recognized by red fins and short head.
Found in European lakes and rivers, up to 60 cm. Highly variable species complex, commercially important.
Endemic to Italy, up to 40 cm. Bottom feeder, important in riverine ecosystems.
A coldwater salmonid of North America, up to 70 cm. Commercially valuable for its flesh and roe.
A cosmopolitan coastal fish, up to 100 cm. Important in aquaculture and coastal fisheries.
Anadromous herring from North America, up to 76 cm. Economically important, introduced worldwide.
A South American predatory cichlid, up to 74 cm. Brightly patterned, valued in sport fishing.
Native to southeastern Australia, up to 75 cm. Found in estuaries and rivers, prized by anglers.
A Chinese cyprinid, up to 40 cm. Important in aquaculture, herbivorous diet.
Catadromous species, up to 150 cm. Spawns in the Sargasso Sea; critically endangered.
A Siberian whitefish, up to 85 cm. Anadromous, valued in Russian fisheries.
A North American sucker fish, up to 60 cm. Found in large rivers, feeds on detritus.
Native to the Orinoco River basin, up to 70 cm. Predatory, with distinctive ocelli (eye-spots) on fins.
The smallest Pacific salmon, up to 76 cm. Distinctive humpback in spawning males.
A North American sucker with long, quill-like dorsal fin ray. Grows up to 60 cm.

The Tanganyika lates is a large perch endemic to Lake Tanganyika, occupying pelagic to benthopelagic zones. Juveniles feed on zooplankton and shrimps, shifting to piscivory as adults. It supports regional fisheries but is sensitive to overharvest and lakewarming-induced stratification changes.

The European chub inhabits cool to warm rivers and lakes across much of Europe. An opportunistic omnivore, it consumes insects, small fish, fruits, and detritus. Hardy and tolerant of moderate pollution, it has benefitted from river engineering in places yet suffers from habitat homogenization.

The barbel is a rheophilic cyprinid of clear, fast rivers with gravel bottoms. Its inferior, fleshy lips and barbels suit benthic foraging on invertebrates and detritus. Many populations declined from weirs, gravel extraction, and altered flows, prompting restoration efforts.

The Ohrid trout, endemic to Lake Ohrid, comprises distinct spawning forms tied to tributaries and seasons. It feeds on benthic invertebrates and fishes in deep oligotrophic waters. Overfishing and habitat alteration reduced stocks; hatchery supplementation and quotas are used.

The American eel is catadromous: it grows in fresh/estuarine waters and spawns in the Sargasso Sea. Glass eels recruit widely along Atlantic North America before dispersing upstream. Dams, turbine mortality, and glass-eel exploitation are key threats.

The bighead walking catfish of Southeast Asia thrives in rice fields, swamps, and canals, breathing air via a suprabranchial organ. Nocturnal and omnivorous, it spawns in rainy-season nests. Aquaculture and habitat loss drive mixed conservation outlooks.

The broad whitefish of Arctic drainages occupies large rivers and lakes, migrating to spawn over gravel. It feeds on benthos and zooplankton and underpins northern subsistence fisheries. Climate change and barriers may disrupt migrations.

A large, piscivorous salmonid historically from Adriatic drainages; taxonomy remains debated. It prefers clear rivers and large lakes, spawning on coarse gravels. Hydropower, flow regulation, and hybridization with stocked trout threaten it.
The hampala barb is a swift Asian predator of forest streams and lowland rivers. Adults hunt fish and shrimps in runs and pools; juveniles form schools. Overfishing and damming fragment populations.

The silver redhorse is a large North American sucker that scrapes periphyton and invertebrates from substrates. It spawns in riffles in spring, often aggregating in large numbers. Sensitive to siltation and barriers that block migrations.

The Black Sea roach complex inhabits lowland rivers and brackish lagoons. An omnivore, it grazes algae and detritus and consumes invertebrates. Eutrophication and water abstraction have reduced some stocks.

The African bonytongue is an air-breathing osteoglossiform from floodplains and swamps. It filter-sifts zooplankton and detritus using gill rakers; nests are guarded by parents. Widely fished and farmed, it is resilient but vulnerable to floodplain loss.

The Indian featherback inhabits sluggish rivers and reservoirs, using undulating fin locomotion. Nocturnal and carnivorous, it preys on fishes and prawns; males guard eggs on submerged structures. Overfishing and pollution impact local stocks.

A keystone detritivore of the Paraná-La Plata basin, making long migrations between feeding and spawning grounds. By bioturbating sediments, it recycles nutrients and fuels fisheries. Dams and floodplain isolation disrupt migrations.

The Asian arowana is a surface predator of forest blackwaters, famed in aquaria. Mouthbrooding males carry fry; wild forms are color-varied. Overharvest and habitat loss led to strict CITES regulation.
The Sultan fish inhabits clear Malaysian rivers, grazing periphyton and fruits in flood seasons. It grows large and is prized as food; also cultured. Logging and damming degrade habitats.
Java barb is a widespread herbivore/detritivore of Southeast Asian lowlands. It thrives in canals and reservoirs and is extensively farmed and stocked. Floodplain connectivity boosts recruitment.

Maraena whitefish is native to Baltic drainages, inhabiting cool lakes and coastal waters. It feeds on zooplankton and benthos and spawns on gravel shoals. Eutrophication and spawning-habitat loss lowered many populations.

The shortfin eel breeds in the South Pacific gyre; juveniles recruit to Australia/NZ coasts. It occupies diverse freshwaters, grows for years, then migrates to spawn once. Commercial fisheries require careful quota and passage management.

Sockeye Salmon use natal homing to spawn in rivers or lake beaches; juveniles rear in lakes. Adults are plankton-feeding in the ocean, turning red during spawning. Sensitive to warming and passage barriers.

Tench prefers vegetated, slow waters of Eurasia. A tolerant, benthic omnivore, it roots for invertebrates and detritus; thick mucus aids low-oxygen survival. It’s introduced widely, sometimes invasive.

The giant gourami is an air-breathing omnivore of SE Asian swamps and rivers. It builds large nests and is a major aquaculture species. Habitat conversion and capture of wild broodstock affect native stocks.

Brook trout inhabit cold, clear streams and lakes in eastern North America. They require high oxygen and complex cover and spawn in upwelling gravels. Stocking and hybridization with introduced char complicate conservation.

The whitespotted char ranges across NE Asia in mountain streams and lakes; some are anadromous. It feeds on aquatic and terrestrial invertebrates and small fish. Dams and warming reduce cold-water refugia.

The tor mahseer is a large, migratory cyprinid of Himalayan foothill rivers. It spawns on clean gravels during monsoon; adults take fruits, invertebrates, and fish. Overfishing and dams have driven declines; restocking programs exist.
The smallmouth yellowfish of southern Africa inhabits large rivers and reservoirs. Omnivorous and long-lived, it underpins sport fisheries. Water abstraction and alien species are key pressures.
A large trahira from Brazilian basins, ambushing fish with powerful jaws. Nocturnal and territorial, it occupies deep pools and vegetated margins. Overfishing and damming threaten some stocks.

The northern snakehead is a predatory air-breather native to East Asia; invasive in North America. It tolerates low oxygen and extreme temperatures, preying on fish and amphibians. Control focuses on preventing spread.

Dolly Varden includes anadromous and resident forms across the North Pacific rim. It feeds on invertebrates and fish; anadromous fish grow quickly at sea. Sensitive to thermal regime shifts and barriers.
The mangrove red snapper is a euryhaline reef-associated predator. Juveniles use estuarine mangroves as nurseries before moving to reefs. Overfishing and mangrove loss are key threats.
Mrigal is a South Asian riverine detritivore/herbivore widely farmed in polyculture. It spawns on floodplains during monsoon rises. Wild stocks declined from damming and overharvest.
The great snakehead is a top predator of South Asian rivers and reservoirs. It feeds on fish, frogs, and crustaceans; pairs guard floating nests. It is valued as food but susceptible to habitat loss.
Wolf cichlid of Central America inhabits rocky rivers and crater lakes. A large, aggressive piscivore with notable parental care. Overfishing and sedimentation threaten some native populations.
The kampango catfish of Lake Malawi is a nocturnal piscivore/invertivore. It nests in caves and provides male parental care. Artisanal fisheries target it; overfishing is a concern.
Clown featherback inhabits floodplains of the Mekong-Chao Phraya; introduced elsewhere. Nocturnal, it preys on fish and prawns; builds nests on submerged structures. Popular in aquaria and fisheries.

A large thorny catfish of the Paraná-Paraguay draining; forms migratory shoals. Omnivorous, it consumes fruits, detritus, and invertebrates. Commercially important but vulnerable to hydrological alteration.
Pacu of the Paraná basin is a frugivore/omnivore that disperses riparian seeds. Fast growth and mild flesh make it a major aquaculture species. Dams disrupt floodplain feeding migrations.
White catfish of Atlantic slope rivers tolerates brackish estuaries. Nocturnal omnivore, spawning in cavities with parental guarding. Introduced in the U.S. West where it can impact natives.
Black rohu inhabits large South Asian rivers, grazing periphyton and detritus. It matures late and is important in aquaculture. Habitat fragmentation and overfishing reduce wild recruitment.

The sterlet is a small sturgeon of large Eurasian rivers; some forms are potamodromous. It feeds on benthos and spawns on clean gravel at high flows. Overfishing and dams have necessitated hatchery support.

The mandarin fish is an apex freshwater predator in East Asia that feeds almost exclusively on live fish. Culturally and economically important in Chinese aquaculture. Habitat degradation and overharvest affect wild stocks.
The kongolo is a deepwater Tanganyika lates preying on clupeids and cichlids. It is long-lived and late-maturing, traits that heighten vulnerability to overfishing.

Asp is a fast, predatory cyprinid of large European rivers and reservoirs. It hunts in open water on bleak and other small fish. Damming created reservoir habitats that aided expansion in some basins.

Walleye of North America favors large lakes and turbid rivers, spawning over clean rubble. Crepuscular predators, they rely on sensitive vision. Fisheries management uses size/slot limits to sustain stocks.
Mud carp from South China rivers is a detritivore/herbivore widely cultured. It tolerates low oxygen and turbid canals. Wild populations face urbanization and flow alteration.
Zebra shovelnose catfish from Amazon-Orinoco inhabits deep channels and flooded forests. A nocturnal piscivore/invertivore that reaches large sizes. Overfishing and damming pressure migratory routes.

Largemouth bass is a premier sport fish native to the SE U.S., introduced worldwide. Ambush predator in vegetated lakes and slow rivers, with nest-guarding males. Stocking has ecological side-effects on native communities.

Shortnose gar is an ancient, air-breathing ambush predator of Mississippi basin backwaters. It tolerates hypoxia and turbidity, feeding on fish and crayfish. Channelization reduced floodplain habitats.

Chum salmon spawn in large lowland rivers; juveniles migrate to sea quickly. Adults feed on pelagic invertebrates and fish; runs support subsistence fisheries. Sensitive to estuarine habitat quality and marine heatwaves.

The Amur pike is a piscivore of the Amur basin’s clear lakes and rivers. It resembles northern pike but with distinct spotting; requires vegetated spawning grounds. Habitat alteration and hybridization risks are noted locally.

Giant mottled eel ranges widely across the Indo-Pacific; highly migratory and catadromous. Juveniles colonize tropical islands far from spawning sites. Overfishing of glass eels and barriers jeopardize stocks.

Spotted gar inhabits vegetated backwaters and oxbows in eastern North America. A stealth predator on fish and crayfish, it spawns on flooded vegetation in spring. Wetland loss has fragmented populations.

Speckled peacock bass is an Amazonian top piscivore of oxbow lakes and slow rivers. Exhibits striking breeding coloration and biparental care. Overfishing for trophy angling and water-level alteration affect recruitment.

The ripsaw catfish is a massive, armored detritivore/picker of flooded forests. It ingests periphyton, fruits, and invertebrates, migrating with rising waters. Heavily targeted in ornamental and food trades.

Tambaqui is a frugivore/omnivore of Amazon-Orinoco floodplains, dispersing tree seeds. It’s a major aquaculture species and important to riverine fisheries. Dams and overharvest reduce wild spawning runs.

The planiceps sorubim is a large sand-dwelling, nocturnal catfish of big Amazonian channels. Piscivorous, it uses a flattened head to ambush prey. Migratory behavior makes it susceptible to river regulation.

Burbot is the only freshwater cod, thriving in cold lakes and rivers of the Holarctic. It spawns under ice, feeding on benthos and fish; juveniles are insectivorous. Warm winters and eutrophication reduce suitability.

Bull trout require cold, clean, connected habitats; many populations are migratory. They prey on fish and invertebrates and spawn in groundwater-fed gravels. Listed as threatened in the U.S. due to warming and fragmentation.

Brown trout includes resident and anadromous forms across Europe and introduced globally. Highly plastic in habitat use and diet, it’s a major sport fish. Stocking and invasive behavior can threaten native faunas.
Coho Salmon rear in cool forested streams for a year, then migrate to sea. Adults home to spawn in small tributaries with complex wood and gravel. Culverts and riparian loss limit production.

New Zealand longfin eel is long-lived (often >50 years) and potamodromous as adults, catadromous overall. It’s an apex freshwater predator; females grow largest. Declines stem from barriers, harvest, and wetland loss.

Golden perch (Australia) is a long-lived, floodplain-spawning predator. Recruitment pulses follow large river floods; flow regulation has altered life cycles. Large-scale environmental flow programs target recovery.
Mekong featherback inhabits deep pools and floodplains, preying on fish and crustaceans. It’s important in regional fisheries but declines with dam development.

The African lungfish inhabits floodplains and swamps, estivating in dry seasons within mucous cocoons. An omnivore with crushing teeth plates, it feeds on snails, fish, and plant matter. Wetland drainage threatens local populations.
Giant snakehead is a fast-growing apex predator of SE Asia; pairs guard fry. Widely fished and introduced, it can restructure communities. Reservoir stocking boosts fisheries but risks invasions.

Arctic char displays extreme life-history diversity from anadromy to lake residency. It occupies cold oligotrophic waters and feeds on zooplankton, benthos, and fish. Climate warming is shrinking thermal habitat.

The Deccan mahseer is a large, migratory cyprinid of peninsular India rivers. It requires clean, fast runs for spawning and deep pools for adults. Dams and sand mining have driven declines; ranching projects exist.

Northern pike is a widespread ambush predator of vegetated lakes and slow rivers. Spring spawner over flooded vegetation, with cannibalistic tendencies. It’s a key sport fish and top-down regulator of prey fish.

Cutthroat trout comprises many subspecies of western North America. Typically insectivorous in streams, lake forms become piscivorous; requires cold, complex habitats. Hybridization with rainbow trout is a major threat.

Channel catfish tolerates warm, turbid rivers and reservoirs; nocturnal omnivore and cavity spawner. It underpins major aquaculture and sport fisheries. Stocking and habitat modifications expanded its range.

European pikeperch occupies large turbid rivers and lakes, hunting by vision in low light. It spawns in shallow nests guarded by males. Eutrophication and reservoir creation aided expansions in Europe.

Rainbow/steelhead is ecologically versatile; anadromous forms rear in rivers 1-3 years before ocean growth. It thrives in cool, well-oxygenated waters; hatchery stocking is widespread. Habitat connectivity and temperature govern persistence.
Inconnu (nelma complex) are large, migratory whitefishes of Arctic basins. Piscivorous adults migrate long distances to spawn. Dams and climate shifts threaten connectivity.

The ocellate river stingray inhabits Amazon-Paraná soft bottoms. It preys on benthos (crustaceans, mollusks) and is viviparous with matrotrophy. Overharvest for ornamental trade and bycatch are concerns.

Dorado is a powerful migratory predator of the Paraná-Uruguay basins. It undertakes long spawning runs and is a premier sport fish. Dams disrupt migrations; protected free-flowing reaches are critical.
Grass carp is a large herbivore used globally for macrophyte control. Highly fecund, with drifting eggs requiring long, warm rivers. Escapes can alter vegetation and habitats if unmanaged.

Striped catfish of Mekong-Chao Phraya is a fast-growing omnivore and major aquaculture staple (pangasius). Wild fish migrate with monsoon hydrology; dams threaten recruitment. Farming raises sustainability concerns but supports protein supply.
A walking catfish from East Asia, up to 50 cm. Air-breathing and hardy.
Endemic to South Africa, up to 90 cm. Prefers rocky, fast-flowing rivers.
A major South Asian carp, up to 200 cm. Key aquaculture species, omnivorous.
A South American catfish, up to 104 cm. Recognized by its striped body and long whiskers.
A North American fish, up to 90 cm. Only freshwater drum species, produces drumming sounds.
A giant knifefish from Southeast Asia, reaching 150 cm. Critically endangered due to overfishing.
A North American percid, up to 49 cm. Inhabits estuaries and rivers, popular sport fish.
A planktivorous Asian carp, up to 140 cm. Introduced worldwide, often invasive.
A large North American pike, up to 183 cm. Apex predator and prized sport fish.
Endemic to the Adriatic basin, up to 120 cm. Distinct marble-like pattern, endangered.
A Eurasian cyprinid, up to 120 cm. Widely farmed and domesticated into ornamental koi.
A large salmonid, up to 150 cm. Anadromous, economically important in aquaculture and fisheries.
A large air-breathing catfish from Africa, up to 170 cm. Important aquaculture species.
A large South Asian carp, up to 182 cm. Major aquaculture species, planktivorous.
A planktivorous Asian carp, up to 146 cm. Introduced globally, often invasive.
A South American characiform, up to 108 cm. Omnivorous, farmed in aquaculture.
A North American sucker, up to 120 cm. Long-lived, planktivorous.
A sturgeon from the Black and Caspian Seas, up to 220 cm. Valued for caviar, critically endangered.
Endemic to the Colorado River, up to 183 cm. Once abundant, now endangered.
A North American migratory percid, up to 150 cm. Important sport and commercial fish.
Endemic to Lake Tanganyika, up to 200 cm. Top predator, important in fisheries.
The largest Pacific salmon, up to 150 cm. Known as king salmon, vital for fisheries.
A North American sucker, up to 120 cm. Bottom feeder, important in commercial fisheries.
A sucker native to North America, up to 120 cm. Rare compared to other buffalos.
A large Asian cyprinid, up to 200 cm. Predatory, inhabits large rivers.
A North American salmonid, up to 127 cm. Deepwater predator, important sport fish.
Native to the Caspian and Black Seas, up to 236 cm. Source of high-value caviar, critically endangered.
A rare sturgeon from the Caspian basin, up to 210 cm. Critically endangered.
A large Indo-Pacific fish, up to 180 cm. Highly valued in aquaculture and fisheries.
A South American giant catfish, up to 134 cm. Distinct red tail, popular aquarium giant.
A North American catfish, up to 155 cm. Nocturnal predator, important sport fish.
A European salmonid, up to 150 cm. Endangered due to habitat loss; iconic game fish.
The largest North American catfish, up to 165 cm. Popular sport and food fish.
A South Asian cyprinid, up to 250 cm. Iconic sport fish, endangered due to overfishing and dams.
A large mollusc-eating Asian carp, up to 200 cm. Introduced in aquaculture.
Australia’s largest freshwater fish, up to 180 cm. Apex predator, important in conservation and fisheries.
A primitive filter-feeding fish from North America, up to 220 cm. Distinct paddle-shaped snout.

Known as the spotted sorubim or surubí, this large predatory catfish is native to the Paraná and São Francisco basins in South America. It inhabits deep channels and floodplains, feeding mainly on smaller fish and crustaceans. Highly valued for commercial and sport fishing, it faces threats from overexploitation and river damming which disrupts its migratory spawning runs.

The lake sturgeon is a long-lived species native to large rivers and lakes of North America. It can exceed 100 years in age and primarily feeds on benthic invertebrates. Populations were drastically reduced by overfishing, habitat destruction, and dams, but conservation and stocking programs have aided recovery.

The Siberian sturgeon inhabits major Siberian rivers and adjacent basins, with some populations living entirely in freshwater. It feeds on mollusks, crustaceans, and insect larvae, and is widely farmed for caviar production. Wild stocks have declined due to damming and poaching.

The Nile perch is a massive piscivore native to African rivers and lakes, most famous for its introduction to Lake Victoria. While it boosted fisheries, it caused major declines in endemic cichlids through predation and competition. It remains both economically important and ecologically controversial.

The alligator gar is one of the largest freshwater fishes in North America, reaching lengths over 3 meters. It inhabits slow rivers, bayous, and reservoirs, preying on fish and waterfowl. Once persecuted, it is now valued for its role as a top predator and subject to conservation initiatives.

The arapaima, or pirarucu, is among the world’s largest freshwater fishes, native to the Amazon basin. It is an obligate air-breather and surface predator of fish and invertebrates. Overfishing and habitat loss reduced wild numbers, but managed harvest and aquaculture have supported recovery.

The Amur sturgeon inhabits the Amur River and adjacent coasts of China and Russia. A benthic feeder, it consumes mollusks and crustaceans and can live over 50 years. It is critically endangered from overfishing and damming, but aquaculture sustains caviar production.

The Wels catfish is a giant freshwater predator native to rivers and lakes of Europe. It hunts fish, amphibians, and sometimes birds, and can grow beyond 200 kg. Introduced widely, it is both valued as a trophy fish and considered invasive in some regions.

The Mekong giant catfish is one of the largest freshwater fish globally, native to the Mekong basin. Once abundant, it is now critically endangered due to overfishing, habitat loss, and damming. It is herbivorous as an adult, feeding on algae and detritus.

The white sturgeon inhabits the Pacific coast of North America, from rivers to estuaries. It is the largest North American freshwater fish, with an anadromous life cycle in some populations. Overharvest and dams reduced numbers, though hatchery programs sustain fisheries.

The beluga sturgeon, native to the Caspian and Black Sea basins, is famed for producing beluga caviar. It can exceed 1,000 kg and is an apex predator on fish and invertebrates. Critically endangered, it suffers from overfishing, poaching, and barriers blocking migrations.

The butterfly splitfin is an endangered goodeid endemic to Mexico’s Ameca River drainage. It inhabits clear streams with rocky substrates, feeding on algae, insects, and detritus. Once nearly extinct in the wild, it survives largely due to aquarium conservation efforts.

This African cichlid inhabits lakes and rivers of East Africa. It is an adaptable omnivore with strong pharyngeal jaws that allow it to crush mollusks. Often used in aquaculture research, it is valued as a model for evolutionary studies.

A versatile cichlid found in Lake Malawi and adjacent rivers, it occupies a wide range of habitats from rocky shores to marshes. It feeds on invertebrates, algae, and detritus, and is known for its vibrant coloration. It plays a role in small-scale fisheries.

Known as the pike killifish, this Central American livebearer is an ambush predator resembling a small pike. It preys heavily on smaller fish and insects. Introduced to Florida, it is considered invasive.

The powder blue cichlid is a popular ornamental fish endemic to Lake Malawi. It inhabits rocky littoral zones, where it grazes algae and defends territories. Overcollection for the aquarium trade poses a risk, though it remains common in the lake.

Native to the Paraná and Paraguay basins, this cichlid inhabits slow-moving waters with vegetation. It is omnivorous and exhibits strong biparental care of eggs and fry. Its adaptability has made it successful in disturbed habitats.

The spring cavefish is endemic to subterranean waters in the central United States. It is adapted to darkness with reduced eyes and pigmentation, feeding on invertebrates in groundwater habitats. Groundwater pollution and aquifer depletion threaten its survival.

The western mosquitofish is one of the world’s most introduced freshwater fishes, released for mosquito control. It is highly adaptable, feeding on insect larvae, algae, and detritus. Invasive populations often displace native fish and amphibians.

The largespring gambusia is endemic to freshwater springs in central Texas. It inhabits clear, vegetated waters and feeds on insects and detritus. Restricted range makes it vulnerable to water extraction and habitat changes.

Commonly called the eastern mosquitofish, this species was widely introduced for mosquito control across the globe. It thrives in a wide range of environments, from stagnant ponds to flowing streams, feeding on insect larvae and algae. Unfortunately, it often outcompetes native fishes and amphibians, leading to biodiversity loss.

Known as the Pecos gambusia, this critically endangered species is restricted to spring-fed waters in Texas and New Mexico. It prefers clear, warm habitats with aquatic vegetation, where it feeds on small invertebrates. Its survival is threatened by groundwater depletion and hybridization with other Gambusia species.

Endemic to the Pánuco River basin in Mexico, this livebearer occupies freshwater streams and quiet backwaters. It is adapted to warm, slow-moving habitats and feeds on insect larvae and detritus. Habitat alteration and pollution threaten its limited populations.

The blotched gambusia is native to northeastern Mexico and southern Texas, where it inhabits springs and streams. It is characterized by dark blotches on its body and a tolerance for brackish waters. Conservation efforts are challenged by water extraction and invasive species.

Known as the banded cichlid or severum, this South American species inhabits slow rivers and floodplains of the Amazon and Orinoco basins. It feeds on plant material, insects, and detritus, and exhibits parental care by guarding eggs on submerged surfaces. Popular in the aquarium trade, it remains widespread in the wild.

The rainbow cichlid is native to Central America and is distinguished by its vibrant coloration. It inhabits lakes and rivers with rocky or sandy substrates, feeding on algae, detritus, and small invertebrates. Highly adaptable, it tolerates a wide range of conditions and is common in aquaria.

Known as the least killifish, it is one of the smallest livebearing fishes, reaching only about 2.5 cm. Native to southeastern United States wetlands, it inhabits vegetated ponds and streams, feeding on algae and tiny invertebrates. Its small size and high reproductive rate make it ecologically significant in aquatic food webs.

The tule perch is endemic to California, inhabiting slow-moving rivers, sloughs, and estuaries. Unique among North American fishes, it is viviparous, giving birth to live young. Once widespread, its distribution is now reduced due to water diversions and habitat degradation.

This Lake Malawi cichlid is well known in aquariums for its bright blue and orange morphs. In the wild, it grazes algae from rocks in shallow, rocky habitats and is highly territorial. Overfishing for the aquarium trade has impacted some populations, though it remains locally abundant.

Native to Cuba, this livebearer occupies a range of freshwater and brackish habitats, including rivers, lagoons, and coastal streams. It feeds on algae, detritus, and insects, playing an important role in local ecosystems. Popular in aquariums, but wild populations are under pressure from habitat loss.

A colorful cichlid endemic to Lake Malawi, known for its striking vertical blue-and-black stripes. It inhabits rocky shorelines where it grazes on algae and detritus. Highly territorial, males defend rocky crevices during breeding, and females mouthbrood their young.

Native to Lake Malawi, this cichlid displays strong sexual dimorphism, with golden females and dark males. It feeds on algae and small invertebrates scraped from rocks in shallow waters. Aggressive and territorial, it is a popular but challenging aquarium species.

Known as the blue tilapia, this species is native to North Africa and the Middle East but introduced worldwide. It tolerates a wide range of salinities and temperatures, making it a successful aquaculture species. It feeds mainly on algae and detritus, and exhibits mouthbrooding behavior.

A tilapia species native to East Africa, primarily in lakes and rivers of the Nile basin. It feeds on plankton and detritus and is often farmed in aquaculture systems. Hybridization with other Oreochromis species has been reported in areas where it was introduced.

Commonly known as the longfin tilapia, it is native to southern Africa, inhabiting rivers, floodplains, and lakes. It feeds on phytoplankton, algae, and detritus, and is a valued food fish. Overfishing and habitat modification have reduced some populations.

This tilapia is restricted to the upper Zambezi River system in Africa. It inhabits vegetated river channels and lagoons, feeding on algae and small invertebrates. Once widespread, it has declined due to competition with introduced tilapias.

A tilapia species from coastal East Africa, tolerant of brackish and fresh waters. It feeds on algae, plankton, and detritus, and is important for local fisheries. Populations are threatened by overfishing and hybridization with farmed tilapias.

The Japanese ricefish or medaka, a small fish widely used in genetic and developmental research. Found in rice paddies, streams, and ponds, it feeds on zooplankton and insect larvae. It is hardy, easy to breed, and important as a model organism.

A small livebearer native to South America, often called the dusky millions fish. It inhabits streams and ponds, feeding on algae and detritus. Hardy and adaptable, it has been introduced outside its range, sometimes becoming invasive.

Known as the sailfin molly, it is native to the southeastern U.S. and Gulf of Mexico. It inhabits freshwater and brackish habitats, where males display large dorsal fins to attract females. It feeds on algae and plant matter and is a popular aquarium fish.

Endemic to Mexico, this molly species inhabits freshwater streams and rivers. It feeds on algae, detritus, and small invertebrates, playing a role in nutrient cycling. Habitat degradation threatens its populations.

Native to Mexico and Central America, this molly is highly adaptable, occurring in fresh, brackish, and even sulfidic waters. It feeds on algae, detritus, and insect larvae. Widely studied for its tolerance to extreme environments.

The guppy, one of the world’s most popular aquarium fish, native to northern South America. Known for its colorful males, it inhabits rivers, streams, and ditches, feeding on algae and insect larvae. It is also used in mosquito control programs worldwide.

The shortfin molly, native to Central America, inhabits rivers, streams, and coastal waters. It feeds on algae, detritus, and small invertebrates. Selective breeding has produced many aquarium color varieties.

The Yucatan molly is recognized by its large sail-like dorsal fin in males. It inhabits brackish coastal lagoons and rivers in Mexico’s Yucatan Peninsula. It feeds primarily on algae and is valued in the aquarium trade.

Known as the dusky splitfin, this species is found in rivers and streams of Mexico and Central America. It inhabits shallow vegetated areas and feeds on algae, detritus, and insects. It reproduces via internal fertilization and livebearing.

Native to the southwestern U.S. and Mexico, it inhabits small streams, ponds, and springs. It feeds on detritus, algae, and small invertebrates. Populations are threatened by groundwater depletion and invasive species.

A brightly colored mbuna cichlid from Lake Malawi, with blue males and orange females. It inhabits rocky shores, grazing on algae and biofilm. Highly aggressive and territorial, it is common in the aquarium trade.

Also known as the two-spot livebearer, this species is found in streams and rivers of Central America. It inhabits vegetated waters, feeding on algae and insect larvae. Its adaptability allows it to persist in disturbed habitats.

The black-chinned tilapia is native to West Africa and is tolerant of both fresh and brackish waters. It feeds on algae and detritus and is important in subsistence fisheries. It also exhibits biparental mouthbrooding behavior.
A West African tilapia inhabiting rivers and lagoons, often in brackish water. It feeds on detritus, plankton, and algae. Considered important for local fisheries and aquaculture potential.

The black-striped pipefish, found in estuaries and coastal lagoons of the Mediterranean and Black Sea. It has an elongated body and exhibits male pregnancy, with males carrying eggs in a brood pouch. It feeds on small crustaceans and zooplankton.

The southern cavefish, found in subterranean waters of the southeastern U.S. Adapted to complete darkness, it lacks pigmentation and functional eyes. It feeds on small invertebrates in groundwater ecosystems.

Known as the green swordtail, native to Central America and popular in aquariums. Males are easily recognized by their elongated tail sword. It inhabits streams and rivers, feeding on algae, detritus, and insect larvae.

The southern platyfish, a small livebearer from Mexico and Central America. It inhabits ponds and slow streams, feeding on algae and detritus. Extensively bred for aquariums, with many color varieties.
Known as the variable platyfish, native to Mexico, inhabiting streams and ponds. It feeds on algae and insects, and its name refers to its highly variable coloration. Popular in aquaria worldwide.
A lesser-known platyfish endemic to northeastern Mexico. It inhabits small freshwater streams with vegetation and feeds on algae and small insects. Threatened by habitat loss and hybridization.

Known as the Amazon molly, it is unique for reproducing by gynogenesis, requiring sperm from related species but not incorporating its DNA. Found in Mexico and Texas, it inhabits shallow vegetated waters. It feeds on algae, detritus, and insect larvae.
A catfish native to West Africa, often found in estuaries and lower rivers. It feeds on benthic invertebrates, small fish, and detritus. It is fished for food and sold in local markets.
The Pahrump poolfish, endemic to desert springs of Nevada, USA. It inhabits warm, spring-fed pools and feeds on insects and algae. Listed as endangered due to habitat loss and limited range.

The ram cichlid, native to the Orinoco basin of Venezuela and Colombia, is highly popular in aquaria. It inhabits warm, slow-moving waters and is known for its vibrant coloration. Exhibits biparental care of eggs and fry.

Known as the orange chromide, this cichlid is native to southern India and Sri Lanka. It inhabits brackish lagoons and rivers, feeding on algae and detritus. It is widely kept in aquariums and used in aquaculture.

Endemic to Lake Guinas in Namibia, this tilapia inhabits deep, clear waters. It feeds on plankton and algae, and males establish territories for breeding. Restricted range makes it vulnerable to environmental changes.

Known as the Chinese false gudgeon, it is native to East Asia, inhabiting rivers, lakes, and reservoirs. It feeds on benthic invertebrates and detritus. Often abundant, it serves as prey for larger fishes.
The yellowfin goby, native to East Asia, inhabits estuaries and coastal rivers. It feeds on benthic invertebrates and small fish. Introduced to California, where it has become invasive.

The convict cichlid, native to Central America, is known for its black vertical stripes. It inhabits streams and lakes with rocky substrates and is highly territorial. Exhibits strong parental care, making it popular in behavioral studies.

Known as the Roanoke bass, this sunfish is native to Virginia and North Carolina rivers. It inhabits clear, rocky streams and feeds on insects, crayfish, and small fish. It is threatened by habitat loss and hybridization with rock bass.

The Midas cichlid, native to Nicaragua and Costa Rica, is recognized for its bright orange coloration in captivity. In the wild, it inhabits volcanic lakes, feeding on plants, snails, and detritus. Known for its aggressive behavior and rapid speciation.

The fourspine stickleback, native to North America, inhabits estuaries, streams, and lakes. Males build nests from vegetation and guard eggs until hatching. It feeds on small invertebrates and plankton.

The pirate perch, endemic to the eastern U.S., inhabits swamps and slow-moving streams. Unique among fishes, its urogenital opening is located near its throat. It feeds on insects and small crustaceans.
The Sacramento perch is native to California, once widespread in rivers and lakes. It is now rare due to competition with introduced species. It feeds on insects, crustaceans, and small fish.

The oscar, native to the Amazon basin, is a large, popular aquarium cichlid. It inhabits slow-moving rivers and floodplains, feeding on insects, crustaceans, and small fish. Known for its intelligence and ability to recognize owners in captivity.

Known as the peaceful betta, this species is native to Southeast Asia. It inhabits rice paddies and streams, breathing air via a labyrinth organ. Less aggressive than Betta splendens, it is still bred for aquaria.

The Siamese fighting fish, native to Thailand and Cambodia, is renowned for its aggressive behavior and vibrant colors. Males build bubble nests and fiercely defend territory. Extensively bred, it is among the world’s most popular aquarium fish.

Native to Colombia and Venezuela, this cichlid inhabits slow-moving rivers and floodplain lakes. It feeds on small invertebrates and plant matter and exhibits parental care. Valued in aquaculture and aquaria.
The flier sunfish, found in slow, vegetated waters of the southeastern U.S. It feeds on insects, crustaceans, and small fish. Popular with anglers but less widespread than other sunfish.
The blotched snakehead, native to China and Vietnam, inhabits ponds, rivers, and rice paddies. It is a predatory species feeding on fish, frogs, and insects. Highly invasive outside its native range.

The shortnose sucker, endemic to Upper Klamath Lake in Oregon, U.S. It inhabits lakes and slow rivers, feeding on algae and detritus. Listed as endangered due to habitat degradation and competition with invasive species.
A South American cichlid inhabiting slow rivers and floodplain lakes. It feeds on plants, detritus, and invertebrates. Known for its adaptability and parental care.

The redbelly tilapia, widespread in Africa and the Middle East, inhabits lakes, rivers, and coastal lagoons. It feeds on algae, detritus, and plants. Introduced to many countries for aquaculture and weed control.
Known as the prickly sculpin, native to western North America. It inhabits rivers, lakes, and estuaries, feeding on insects, crustaceans, and small fish. It is adaptable and important in food webs.
The mottled sculpin, native to cold, clear streams across North America. It feeds on aquatic insects, small crustaceans, and fish eggs. Considered an indicator of water quality.

The European bullhead, widespread across Europe in cool, clear rivers and streams. It is a benthic species feeding on insect larvae and small invertebrates. Sensitive to pollution, it is used as a bioindicator.
A small cichlid from Central America, inhabiting rivers with rocky and sandy substrates. It feeds on algae, insects, and detritus and exhibits parental care. Sometimes kept in aquaria.
A labyrinth fish native to Central Africa, inhabiting slow, vegetated waters. It feeds on insects, crustaceans, and small fish. Uses its labyrinth organ to breathe atmospheric air.
The brook stickleback, native to North America, inhabits small streams, ponds, and lakes. Males build nests and guard eggs aggressively. It feeds on insect larvae, zooplankton, and detritus.
The spotfin shiner, widespread in eastern North America. It inhabits streams and rivers, feeding on insects and algae. Males develop bright breeding colors in the spawning season.
The Alaska blackfish, native to Alaska and Siberia, inhabits cold, vegetated wetlands. It can breathe air and survive in low-oxygen conditions. It feeds on invertebrates and small fish.

The green spotted pufferfish, found in brackish and freshwater habitats of Southeast Asia. It feeds on mollusks, crustaceans, and snails, using its strong beak-like teeth. A popular aquarium species, though requiring special care.

The bluespotted sunfish, native to the eastern U.S., inhabits vegetated ponds, swamps, and streams. It feeds on insects and small crustaceans. Its small size and tolerance of low-oxygen habitats make it adaptable.

Known as the Arkansas darter, native to the central U.S. It inhabits cool, clear streams with sandy substrates, feeding on insects and small invertebrates. Considered near threatened due to habitat alteration.
The johnny darter, widespread across North America, inhabits streams and lakes with sandy bottoms. It feeds on aquatic insects and larvae and is recognized for its mottled color pattern.
Known as the watercress darter, endemic to Alabama, U.S. It inhabits spring-fed creeks with aquatic vegetation and feeds on small invertebrates. Listed as endangered due to restricted distribution.
The tessellated darter, native to eastern North America, inhabits streams and rivers with sandy or gravelly substrates. It feeds on insect larvae and small invertebrates. It is widespread and common.

The three-spined stickleback, widespread across the Northern Hemisphere. It inhabits fresh and coastal waters, known for its elaborate courtship and nesting behavior. A model organism in evolutionary biology.
A goby species native to the Indo-Pacific, inhabiting estuaries, rivers, and coastal lagoons. It feeds on benthic invertebrates and detritus. Important for small-scale fisheries.

The jewel cichlid, native to West Africa, is recognized by its bright red coloration with iridescent spots. It inhabits rivers and lakes, feeding on insects, crustaceans, and small fish. Aggressive but popular in aquaria.

A jewel cichlid species from West Africa, inhabiting rivers with rocky and sandy substrates. It feeds on insects and small fish and is known for its territorial behavior. Sometimes collected for aquaria.

The banded jewel cichlid, native to West Africa, is larger than other Hemichromis species. It feeds on invertebrates and small fishes and is known for its aggressiveness. Important in local fisheries.

The African jewelfish, distributed across North Africa and introduced elsewhere. It inhabits rivers and lakes and feeds on insects, crustaceans, and small fishes. It is invasive in some areas, outcompeting native species.
Known as the Texas cichlid, native to northeastern Mexico. It inhabits rivers and lakes, feeding on detritus, plants, and invertebrates. It is the only cichlid native to the United States.
Another form of the Texas cichlid, characterized by blue-green spots on its body. It feeds on plants, detritus, and invertebrates. Commonly found in the Rio Grande basin.

Endemic to Cuatro Ciénegas in Mexico, this cichlid shows trophic polymorphism with different jaw forms. It inhabits springs and streams, feeding variably on snails, algae, or detritus. It is critically endangered due to habitat loss.
A South American armored catfish inhabiting rivers and floodplains. It can breathe atmospheric air and survives in low-oxygen waters. Valued as a food fish in parts of South America.

Known as the moga, a cichlid from Central America inhabiting lakes and rivers. It feeds on detritus, plants, and invertebrates and exhibits biparental care. Popular in aquaria for its golden coloration.

The silver lamprey, native to North America, is a parasitic lamprey that attaches to fish and feeds on blood. It inhabits rivers and lakes, spawning in gravel streams. Unlike invasive sea lampreys, it coexists with native fishes.

The headwater catfish, native to Texas and Mexico. It inhabits small rivers and streams with rocky bottoms and feeds on insects, crustaceans, and small fishes. Populations are declining due to habitat loss.
Known as the flagfish, native to Florida and Cuba. It inhabits vegetated ponds, swamps, and slow rivers, feeding on algae, detritus, and insects. Used in aquaria and mosquito control programs.
A very small goby native to the Black and Caspian Sea drainages, usually found in shallow coastal waters and estuaries.
Known as the warmouth, this North American sunfish has a large mouth, mottled brown pattern, and prefers vegetated lakes and slow rivers.
The bluegill is a common sunfish of North America, recognized by its deep body and black ear flap, important in sport fishing.
Called the longear sunfish, it is small, brightly colored, and notable for its elongated opercular flap, inhabiting clear streams.
Known as the redear sunfish or shellcracker, this species feeds on snails and mollusks and is a popular game fish in the southeastern USA.
The spotted sunfish is a small, dark-spotted sunfish of the southeastern USA, thriving in rivers, swamps, and backwaters.
A South American characiform fish with striking black and yellow vertical bands, often kept in aquariums for its active behavior.
Known as the sunbleak, this small European cyprinid forms large shoals in rivers and lakes, serving as prey for larger fishes.
The paradise fish is a hardy, colorful labyrinth fish from East Asia, among the first species kept in aquariums.

A cavefish from Cuba, adapted to dark subterranean waters. It feeds on small crustaceans and detritus. Its populations are highly localized and vulnerable.
A sea catfish from northern Australia and Papua New Guinea. It inhabits estuaries and coastal rivers, feeding on crustaceans and small fish. It is important in local fisheries.
A tilapia native to Lake Chungruru in Tanzania. It feeds on phytoplankton and algae. It is considered endangered due to habitat changes.
A tilapia from Lake Jipe, Kenya–Tanzania border. It feeds on algae and plankton. Populations are declining due to overfishing and water extraction.

From Lake Victoria, this species inhabits rocky littoral zones. It feeds on insect larvae and detritus. Populations have declined drastically.
Endemic to Lake Victoria, living in sandy and rocky habitats. It is omnivorous, consuming insects, algae, and detritus. It is now considered rare.
A Lake Victoria cichlid named after researcher Katunzi. It inhabits shallow waters and feeds on aquatic invertebrates. It is vulnerable due to invasive species.

The Treur River barb, native to South Africa. It lives in cool, clear headwaters and is critically endangered due to habitat loss and invasive predators.
The flat-headed galaxias, native to southeastern Australia. It inhabits rivers and streams, preying on small invertebrates, and is threatened by trout introduction.
The saddled galaxias, endemic to Tasmania. It is a small-bodied stream fish now endangered due to predation by introduced salmonids.
The bonytail chub, native to the Colorado River Basin. It is adapted to large rivers, with a streamlined body and powerful swimming ability, but is critically endangered.

A Madagascar rainbowfish inhabiting forest streams. Its populations are threatened by deforestation and invasive species.
The redfin blue-eye, native to Queensland, Australia. It is critically endangered due to invasive gambusia and habitat decline.
A small cyprinid endemic to Turkey. It inhabits clear springs and streams but is endangered by groundwater extraction.
A cyprinid from Lake Dianchi, China. It is nearly extinct in the wild due to pollution and introduced species.

The Valencia toothcarp, endemic to Spain’s coastal wetlands. It is critically endangered due to urbanization and water extraction.

A catfish native to Colombian Andean streams. It clings to rocks in fast-flowing waters; highly localized distribution makes it vulnerable.

A mahseer from the Western Ghats, India. Inhabits upland rivers and is locally important for fisheries.
An elephantfish from the Nile and East African rivers. Nocturnal, it uses electric discharges to forage.
The banded knifefish, widely distributed in South America. Produces weak electric fields for navigation and hunting.
The river blackfish, endemic to southeastern Australia. It inhabits cool streams with cover and is threatened by habitat degradation.
The starry flounder, a benthic flatfish found in North Pacific coastal waters. It supports local fisheries.

The Sonora sucker, native to rivers in the southwestern USA and Mexico. It feeds on algae and detritus.

A brilliantly colored cichlid endemic to the rocky shores of Lake Victoria, East Africa. Males exhibit vivid red, orange, and yellow body colors during breeding, while females are drab for camouflage. It is primarily an algae scraper, playing an important role in the lake’s ecological balance. Populations have declined drastically due to Nile perch predation, eutrophication, and hybridization, making it endangered.

Endemic to Lake Victoria, this haplochromine is distinguished by its brilliant blue coloration in males. It inhabits rocky and sandy shallows, feeding mainly on small invertebrates and algae. Once abundant, it suffered steep population crashes after the introduction of Nile perch. Remaining populations are fragmented but still critical to Lake Victoria’s biodiversity.

A cichlid restricted to Lake Victoria, notable for its red-colored head and fins in breeding males. It is specialized in feeding on small invertebrates and plankton in shallow waters. This species has seen dramatic population reductions since the Nile perch boom in the 1980s. Conservation measures focus on maintaining rocky refuges where remnant populations persist.

Found in Lake Victoria and its surrounding rivers, this cichlid is more habitat-flexible than some of its relatives. It feeds on invertebrates, algae, and detritus, helping recycle nutrients. Although impacted by Nile perch, it has shown resilience in turbid and disturbed habitats. Its adaptability has allowed it to survive where many other haplochromines have disappeared.

Endemic to Lake Victoria, this species is identified by its reddish tail fin. It prefers shallow, rocky habitats where it feeds on benthic invertebrates. Populations have been reduced by overfishing and Nile perch predation. Pollution and habitat degradation remain ongoing threats to its survival.

A Lake Victoria haplochromine specialized for insect feeding, with elongated jaws adapted to its diet. Males are colorful during breeding, while females remain cryptically patterned. Its numbers declined significantly with the introduction of Nile perch and increased eutrophication. Conservation relies on protecting rocky shore refuges where this species still survives.

Commonly known as the belly barbel pipefish, it inhabits estuaries, mangroves, and seagrass beds across the Indo-Pacific. Its elongated body and prehensile tail allow it to camouflage among vegetation while feeding on small crustaceans. Like other pipefishes, males brood the eggs until hatching. Coastal development and mangrove clearance threaten local populations.

A fork-tailed catfish native to rivers and floodplains of New Guinea. It is important for local fisheries, providing a protein source for communities. The species feeds on a wide range of aquatic invertebrates and detritus, showing ecological flexibility. It faces increasing pressure from overfishing and habitat disturbance.

A miniature livebearer from Colombia and Venezuela, inhabiting slow-flowing streams and ponds. It is unusual among poeciliids for producing very small litters of large offspring. Its small size and vegetated habitat make it vulnerable to environmental changes. Although not commercially important, it is sometimes studied in reproductive biology.

The Korogwe tilapia is native to rivers and coastal lakes of Tanzania and Kenya. It is valued in local fisheries but hybridizes easily with introduced Nile tilapia, threatening its genetic integrity. It feeds on algae and detritus, contributing to nutrient recycling in shallow waters. Conservation efforts include identifying pure populations for protection.

Known as the Celebes ricefish, it is endemic to Sulawesi, Indonesia, inhabiting lakes, rivers, and brackish estuaries. It has transparent fins and a small body, making it popular in the aquarium trade. The species is hardy, feeding on zooplankton and insect larvae. Habitat alteration in Sulawesi threatens its natural populations.

A southern African cichlid, found in rivers of Botswana, Namibia, and South Africa. It has sharp jaws adapted for preying on mollusks, insects, and fish. It is ecologically significant in river food webs and supports small-scale fisheries. Increasing water abstraction and pollution are emerging threats.

A catfish species inhabiting estuaries and lower river reaches along Mexico’s Pacific coast. It is a demersal fish, often found in muddy substrates where it feeds on benthic invertebrates. While not heavily exploited, it has local importance in artisanal fisheries. Its restricted range makes it sensitive to coastal habitat degradation.

A small livebearing fish from Central America, inhabiting streams with dense aquatic vegetation. It feeds on algae and small invertebrates, displaying resilience to varied environmental conditions. Its reproductive strategy includes internal fertilization and live birth, typical of poeciliids. Agricultural runoff and habitat changes pose localized threats.

A halfbeak species distributed in South and Southeast Asia. It inhabits rivers, estuaries, and coastal lagoons, where it skims the surface for insects and plankton. Its elongated lower jaw is a key adaptation for surface feeding. The species is locally caught for food but not considered threatened.

A small sea catfish native to New Guinea estuaries and coastal rivers. It lives in brackish muddy habitats, feeding on invertebrates. Local communities harvest it for subsistence, though it is not a major commercial species. Pollution and overfishing in estuaries could impact its populations in the future.

Daniel’s catfish, found in freshwater and brackish rivers of Papua New Guinea. It is a benthic feeder, consuming crustaceans and insect larvae at night. It has significance for subsistence fisheries in rural areas. Habitat disturbance from logging and mining threatens its ecosystem.

A small halfbeak from Southeast Asia, typically inhabiting canals, ditches, and streams. It feeds at the water’s surface on insects and small invertebrates. Unlike many relatives, it is adapted to human-modified habitats. It is occasionally kept in aquaria but faces pressure from urbanization.

A colorful Lake Victoria cichlid, with males displaying either red-backed or blue-backed morphs. It is a model species for evolutionary biology, particularly in studies of sexual selection and speciation. It grazes on algae and invertebrates along rocky substrates. Populations remain vulnerable to hybridization and predation pressures.

Endemic to Lake Victoria, males of this species show striking red fins during breeding. It lives in shallow rocky habitats where it feeds on small invertebrates. Its populations have declined due to invasive Nile perch and water pollution. Remaining groups are fragmented and under conservation concern.

A Lake Victoria haplochromine with reddish hues across the body, particularly in males. It feeds on algae and aquatic insects, contributing to nutrient cycling. Like many haplochromines, its numbers plummeted after the Nile perch invasion. It remains rare and conservation dependent.

A poorly known haplochromine cichlid from Lake Victoria. It has unique jaw adaptations suited for specialized feeding strategies. Its populations are believed to have declined sharply after the Nile perch boom. Research is limited, and it may be highly vulnerable to extinction.

A small livebearer from South American freshwater streams. It is unusual for having asymmetric gonopodia, a reproductive adaptation. Females give birth to live young after internal fertilization. Though not of economic importance, it plays a role in controlling insect populations.

A sea catfish native to estuaries of northern Australia and New Guinea. It prefers muddy coastal rivers where it feeds on benthic invertebrates and detritus. It supports small-scale local fisheries. Estuarine degradation and overfishing are potential concerns for its sustainability.

A viviparous halfbeak endemic to Sulawesi, Indonesia, where males have modified anal fins for internal fertilization. It inhabits clear forest streams and feeds on small insects near the water’s surface. This reproductive strategy is rare among halfbeaks, making it of scientific interest. Its populations are threatened by deforestation and water pollution.

Another Sulawesi endemic viviparous halfbeak, restricted to freshwater habitats. It lives in streams with dense vegetation, providing cover for its young. It is threatened by habitat destruction and the introduction of non-native species. Its limited range makes it especially vulnerable.

The black tilapia, native to rivers and lakes in East Africa, especially Malawi and Tanzania. It is a benthic feeder consuming algae, plants, and detritus. Widely used in aquaculture, it often hybridizes with other tilapia species, reducing genetic purity. Populations in the wild are under stress from overfishing and habitat degradation.

A livebearing poeciliid from Brazil, inhabiting small streams and ponds. It feeds on algae, detritus, and tiny invertebrates, making it ecologically important in nutrient cycling. It is small-bodied and produces multiple litters per year. Habitat pollution and human disturbance threaten localized populations.

A freshwater grunter native to rivers and estuaries of New Guinea and northern Australia. It forms schools in slow-flowing rivers, feeding on invertebrates and algae. It is moderately important in local subsistence fisheries. Floodplain alteration and overharvesting are pressures it faces.

A mountain catfish native to rivers of southern Africa, including KwaZulu-Natal. It inhabits rocky, fast-flowing streams where it clings to the substrate. It feeds mainly on insect larvae, helping control aquatic invertebrate populations. It is sensitive to sedimentation and water pollution.

A medium-sized cichlid native to Central America, found in rivers and lagoons from Panama to Colombia. It is notable for its blue-spotted body, with males developing more intense coloration during breeding. The species is omnivorous, feeding on algae, detritus, and small invertebrates. While not globally threatened, habitat pollution and damming of rivers impact some populations.

Often confused with the “green terror,” this South American cichlid is native to Pacific coastal rivers of Peru. It displays vivid green, blue, and gold hues, especially in breeding males. Aggressive and territorial, it plays an important role in controlling benthic invertebrates. Widely kept in aquaria, but wild populations face local declines due to water contamination.

A freshwater cyprinid endemic to rivers and lakes in Japan. It prefers clear, fast-flowing streams where it feeds on aquatic insects and algae. Overfishing and dam construction have fragmented its populations, leading to conservation concerns. It remains ecologically significant as part of the river food web.

Known as the slimy sculpin, this species inhabits cold, rocky streams and lakes across North America and parts of Asia. It has a mottled body that provides camouflage among stones. As a benthic predator, it feeds on insect larvae and small crustaceans, serving as an important prey fish for trout and salmon. Although common, it is sensitive to pollution and sedimentation.
