A cichlid from Central America, distributed mainly in Honduran rivers. Males have noticeably elongated fins, used in displays during territorial defense and breeding. The species feeds on algae and detritus, scraping surfaces of rocks and submerged wood. Habitat loss and deforestation of riparian zones threaten its populations.

Endemic to Guatemala and Honduras, this riverine cichlid prefers clear, fast-flowing waters with rocky substrates. It exhibits parental care, with both sexes guarding eggs and fry. Local communities occasionally catch it for food, though it is not a major fishery species. Deforestation and water pollution are the main conservation concerns.

A robust-bodied cichlid from Central American rivers. It is benthic, feeding on algae, detritus, and small invertebrates. Territorial males defend nesting sites during breeding, showing typical cichlid parental care. Increasing agricultural runoff threatens water quality within its habitat.

One of Europe’s smallest freshwater fish, endemic to Greece. It inhabits coastal lagoons, rivers, and brackish marshes. Adults reach only 3–4 cm, but they form large schools and feed on zooplankton. Habitat destruction and water abstraction make it vulnerable, with some populations critically endangered.

The Pacific lamprey, an anadromous species native to rivers of western North America. It migrates to the ocean after hatching and later returns to rivers to spawn, similar to salmon. Adults parasitize fish in marine environments, attaching with their toothed oral disc. Dams, water diversion, and pollution have caused sharp population declines, leading to restoration programs.

The fantail darter, distributed across eastern North America. Males develop enlarged dorsal fins with orange highlights during breeding season, which they use to attract females and fan oxygen-rich water over eggs. It lives in riffles of clear streams, feeding on aquatic insects. Although common, it is sensitive to siltation and pollution.

A grunter species restricted to rivers and billabongs of northern Australia. It feeds on aquatic invertebrates and algae, often forming small schools in shallow waters. Little is known about its ecology compared to other grunters, but it plays a role in local food webs. Habitat changes from grazing and water extraction may pose risks.

A freshwater grunter from rivers of Papua New Guinea. It is a benthic omnivore feeding on invertebrates and detritus. The species is locally important to small-scale fisheries. Logging and mining activities along rivers threaten its habitats.

Known as Jenkins’ grunter, native to northern Australia. It inhabits clear, rocky rivers and is recognized for its silvery body and strong jaws. It preys mainly on insects, crustaceans, and small fish. Although not heavily fished, water diversion and invasive species are growing threats.

A striped grunter distributed in northern Australia. Juveniles are commonly found in floodplain lagoons, while adults occupy larger rivers. It is a predator of aquatic invertebrates and small fish. Human impacts, especially altered floodplain connectivity, have reduced habitat availability.

Endemic to New Guinea, this freshwater grunter inhabits inland rivers and streams. It has a robust body adapted to strong currents. Its diet consists of aquatic invertebrates and organic matter. Limited distribution makes it susceptible to localized threats such as mining and deforestation.

A freshwater grunter from Papua New Guinea, easily recognized by its large scales. It inhabits rivers, floodplains, and lagoons, where it feeds on aquatic insects. The species is understudied but is locally fished. It could be vulnerable to increasing deforestation and hydrological changes.

A South American characiform widely distributed in the Paraná–Paraguay river basins. It has a blunt snout and striped body, characteristic of the genus. Omnivorous, it feeds on fruits, seeds, and aquatic vegetation, playing a role in seed dispersal. Overfishing and habitat fragmentation affect wild populations.

A Leporinus species endemic to Ecuador’s Amazon tributaries. It inhabits clear, fast-flowing rivers where it feeds on fruits, algae, and aquatic invertebrates. Knowledge of its ecology is limited, but it contributes to local food chains. Deforestation and gold mining are threats to its river habitats.

A large characiform native to South America, reaching up to 80 cm in length. It is herbivorous, feeding on aquatic plants, fruits, and seeds, and is significant in seed dispersal for riparian vegetation. Extensively used in aquaculture and fisheries, it supports local economies. Overfishing and river damming have fragmented natural populations.

The southern purple-spotted gudgeon, once widespread in southeastern Australia but now greatly reduced. It inhabits slow-moving rivers and wetlands, with striking purple spots along its body. It is carnivorous, feeding on small fish and invertebrates, and exhibits parental care. Habitat loss, invasive species, and water regulation have caused population declines.

A medium-sized cichlid endemic to Haiti and the Dominican Republic. It inhabits rivers and lakes, showing black-and-white body patterns in males. Highly territorial during breeding, it practices biparental care of offspring. Deforestation and pollution of freshwater bodies threaten its long-term survival.

A Mexican cichlid formerly placed in Herichthys, endemic to rivers in northeastern Mexico. It is recognized by spotted patterns across its body. Like other cichlids, it practices parental care, with both sexes guarding the young. Restricted distribution and habitat modification make it vulnerable.

A sleeper goby distributed in Southeast Asia. It inhabits sluggish rivers, swamps, and floodplain wetlands, where it remains hidden near substrates. It is a predatory species feeding on small fish and crustaceans. Habitat degradation from agriculture threatens localized populations.

Found in New Guinea and northern Australia, this sleeper goby inhabits freshwater lagoons and rivers. It is a benthic predator feeding on crustaceans and insect larvae. Its cryptic coloration allows it to remain hidden among substrates. Although not threatened globally, localized impacts of mining and agriculture affect habitats.

A migratory characiform from northeastern Brazil, locally known as curimatã. It undertakes spawning migrations during floods, moving upstream to breed. Its diet consists of detritus and algae, contributing significantly to nutrient cycling. Overfishing and dam construction have severely impacted its migration routes.

The spike-tailed paradise fish, native to southern India and Sri Lanka. It inhabits rice paddies, ponds, and slow rivers, building bubble nests for reproduction. Males guard the nests and provide care for the developing fry. Habitat loss and agricultural runoff threaten wild populations.

An amphidromous goby found in Indo-Pacific islands. Adults live in mountain streams, while larvae drift to the sea before migrating back upstream. It has a streamlined body for clinging to rocks in swift currents. Deforestation and damming that block migrations threaten its populations.

A small, amphidromous goby distributed across Indo-Pacific rivers. Males develop striking colors—blue, orange, or black—during the breeding season. It clings to rocks in fast-flowing streams, feeding on algae and detritus. Habitat disruption and blocked migratory pathways threaten its persistence.

A herbivorous grunter native to northern Australia. It scrapes algae from rocks, playing an important ecological role in river ecosystems. The species forms schools and is adapted to fast-flowing rivers. Altered river flows from dams and water extraction are threats.

Another algal-grazing grunter from northern Australian rivers. It has a triangular-shaped head and strong jaws for scraping algae. It is poorly studied but is thought to be ecologically significant for maintaining algal balance in rivers. Its range is limited, making it vulnerable to hydrological changes.

A freshwater cyprinid endemic to central Mexico. It inhabits cool, clear rivers and lakes at higher elevations. It feeds on algae, detritus, and invertebrates, contributing to aquatic food webs. Agricultural runoff and habitat modification are the main threats to its survival.

A small mountain catfish native to East African rivers. It inhabits rocky, turbulent waters where it feeds on insect larvae. Its flattened body and downward-facing mouth are adaptations for clinging to substrates. Although not globally threatened, it is sensitive to habitat disturbance.

Dahl’s catfish, endemic to northern Australia. It inhabits freshwater rivers, often sheltering among rocks and submerged logs. A nocturnal predator, it feeds on insect larvae, small fish, and crustaceans. Logging and agricultural expansion threaten its riverine habitats.

The river goby, widely distributed across the Indo-Pacific. It is amphidromous, with larvae that develop in estuaries before adults migrate to freshwater streams. Adapted to fast currents, it clings to rocks with fused pelvic fins. Overfishing and dam construction disrupt its migratory routes.

A sleeper goby native to Southeast Asia. It occupies rivers, estuaries, and brackish lagoons, showing high salinity tolerance. It is a nocturnal ambush predator feeding on crustaceans and small fishes. Mangrove loss and estuarine pollution are the main threats.

The upland bully, a freshwater goby endemic to New Zealand. It prefers cold, clear lakes and rivers, where it feeds on insect larvae and small crustaceans. It is vulnerable to competition and predation from introduced trout. Habitat alteration has fragmented some populations.

An mbuna cichlid from Lake Malawi, known for its brilliant yellow coloration in males. It inhabits rocky shores where it grazes algae and periphyton. Like other mbuna, it is highly territorial and practices maternal mouthbrooding. Overfishing and the aquarium trade have pressured wild populations.

A gudgeon native to Papua New Guinea, living in small streams and forest creeks. It is a benthic carnivore, feeding on insect larvae and crustaceans. Its spotted body pattern provides camouflage among rocks and vegetation. Logging and mining activities threaten water clarity in its habitat.

A fork-tailed catfish endemic to northern Australia. It is a benthic species, feeding on aquatic invertebrates at night. It inhabits rivers and floodplain lagoons, supporting small subsistence fisheries. Habitat degradation is a concern for its long-term stability.

The Tamaulipas shiner, restricted to northeastern Mexico. It inhabits clear, spring-fed streams with rocky bottoms. It forms schools and feeds on small insects and algae, contributing to local food chains. Water abstraction and pollution have placed it under threat.

A Mexican shiner found in headwater streams of the Chihuahua region. It prefers cool, flowing waters with gravel substrates. It feeds on aquatic insects and detritus, forming schools for protection. Limited range and increasing agricultural activity pose risks to survival.

A cichlid endemic to Madagascar’s eastern rivers and lakes. It has a deep-bodied shape and is often silver with red fins. It is harvested for food, but deforestation and invasive species threaten its populations. Conservation programs are focusing on captive breeding and habitat restoration.

A molluscivorous cichlid from the upper Zambezi River basin. It crushes snails and small mollusks with strong pharyngeal jaws. It is important for local fisheries, providing food security for riparian communities. Habitat alteration and overfishing are emerging concerns.

A goby distributed in Southeast Asia and Pacific islands, inhabiting clear mountain streams. Males exhibit striking purple coloration during the breeding season. Amphidromous in life cycle, larvae drift to the sea before returning to freshwater as juveniles. Damming of rivers poses significant risks.

Another amphidromous goby from Pacific islands, known for its vivid red-and-gold breeding males. It grazes algae from rocks in swift mountain streams. Populations are sensitive to river fragmentation and sedimentation. It is sometimes collected for the aquarium trade.

A pufferfish found in coastal waters of Japan, Korea, and China. Like other Takifugu, it contains tetrodotoxin, making it dangerous if improperly prepared as food. It inhabits sandy bottoms and feeds on mollusks and crustaceans. Coastal fishing pressures and habitat pollution affect its populations.

A small cyprinid endemic to freshwater streams in Mexico. It is part of a diverse group adapted to arid environments. The species feeds on algae, detritus, and invertebrates. Agricultural pollution and reduced water flows are the main threats.

A cichlid native to West Africa, particularly Ghana and Ivory Coast. It prefers rivers and reservoirs, where it feeds on detritus and algae. The species is locally fished for food and sometimes used in aquaculture. Habitat modification and hybridization with introduced tilapias are threats.

A goby native to Japan and Korea, inhabiting estuaries and rivers. It tolerates a wide salinity range, living in both brackish and freshwater environments. It feeds on small crustaceans and worms in muddy substrates. Industrial pollution and habitat alteration are major concerns.

An mbuna cichlid from Lake Malawi, associated with rocky habitats. It grazes algae and biofilm, showing strong territorial behavior among males. Females are mouthbrooders, protecting fry until independence. It is vulnerable to overfishing and collection for the aquarium trade.

An elephantfish from African rivers, known for its elongated snout and weak electric organ. It uses electric fields to navigate and communicate in turbid waters. It feeds on small invertebrates, algae, and detritus. Habitat degradation and overfishing are pressures on its populations.

Another African mormyrid with electrolocation abilities. It inhabits slow-moving rivers and floodplains, feeding on insect larvae and detritus. It produces electric signals for communication, especially during courtship. Increasing agricultural runoff affects water quality in its habitats.

A cyprinid fish endemic to rivers of the Arabian Peninsula. It inhabits rocky and sandy stretches of wadis, surviving in seasonal flows. It feeds on algae and invertebrates, showing ecological adaptability. Water extraction and climate change threaten its persistence.

A small airbreathing catfish endemic to East African rivers. It lives in slow-flowing, vegetated waters where it feeds on insects and detritus. Its ability to breathe air allows it to tolerate hypoxic conditions. Agricultural expansion and habitat destruction pose risks.

A small cyprinid from Middle Eastern rivers, adapted to arid conditions. It has reduced eyes compared to related species, a possible adaptation to turbid waters. It feeds on algae and detritus. Water abstraction and drought are major threats.

A small African barb found in rivers and streams from Tanzania to Mozambique. It inhabits shallow, vegetated habitats, feeding on insects and plant matter. It forms schools and is ecologically important for controlling mosquito larvae. Deforestation and agricultural pollution are threats.

A bottom-dwelling cyprinid native to Iran’s rivers and streams. It uses a specialized adhesive disc to cling to rocks in fast-flowing water. Its diet consists mainly of algae, making it an important grazer. Water extraction and habitat degradation are ongoing threats.

Known as the Malabar labeo, native to rivers of southern India. It inhabits clear, fast-flowing rivers with rocky substrates. Feeding mainly on algae and detritus, it plays an important role in nutrient cycling. Overfishing, pollution, and river damming are major pressures.

A benthic cyprinid native to the Indus–Ganges drainages, frequenting moderate-current rivers with sandy to gravelly bottoms. It grazes periphyton and detritus using a fleshy, infero-terminal mouth with keratinized lips. Spawning follows monsoon rises, with eggs broadcast in shallow riffles. Local pressures include sand mining and seasonal water abstraction.

The Moggel of southern Africa inhabits lowland rivers, pans, and impoundments, tolerating turbid water. It is an omnivorous benthic feeder (detritus, algae, invertebrates) and undertakes upstream movements to spawn on flooded margins. Ecologically, it is important in nutrient recycling and as prey for piscivores. Over-abstraction and eutrophication affect many catchments.

A hill-stream cyprinid of the Western Ghats, India, occupying clear rocky runs. A subterminal mouth with horny sheaths allows scraping algae and biofilm; it also takes aquatic insects. Breeding coincides with southwest monsoon flows, dispersing larvae downstream. Hydropower regulation and siltation threaten riffle habitat.

Small barb from peninsular India’s shaded streams and pools, often over leaf litter. Males intensify dark flank spots during courtship; shoals pick at algae and small invertebrates. It matures quickly and spawns multiple batches in warm months. Catchment deforestation and pesticide runoff reduce local abundances.

South Asian barb of sluggish rivers, rice fields, and seasonal wetlands. It is an opportunistic omnivore grazing aufwuchs and detritus, and forms mixed-species schools. Recruits surge with monsoon flooding as floodplain nurseries become available. Urbanization and agrochemicals degrade shallow habitats.

Western Ghats cyprinid restricted to fast, clear hill streams. Deep-bodied adults browse periphyton and drifting insects; juveniles shelter among boulders. Spawning is timed to early monsoon spates. Range fragmentation from dams and sand extraction is the principal risk.

A high-altitude schizothoracine (“snow trout”) from the Tibetan Plateau and Trans-Himalaya. Cold-adapted, it inhabits swift stony rivers and proglacial lakes, feeding on benthic algae and chironomids. Slow growth and late maturity make it sensitive to harvest. Glacier retreat and altered hydrology threaten headwaters.

The Eastern sand darter of the Great Lakes–Ohio drainages lives buried in clean sand runs. Semi-transparent body and reduced pigmentation aid crypsis; it ambush-feeds on micro-invertebrates. It requires shifting, silt-free sand, making it a strong indicator of channel health. Siltation and channelization have caused major declines.

A small anchovy endemic to the western Caribbean (Belize–adjacent). It forms schools in coastal lagoons and nearshore waters, filtering zooplankton and providing forage for piscivores. Spawning is pelagic, with larvae developing in estuarine nursery zones. Mangrove loss and coastal eutrophication are local threats.

Tiny Asian topminnow of shaded ditches, rice fields, and forest pools from India to Sri Lanka. Surface-oriented jaws take insect fall-out and mosquito larvae; males display subtle fin edging. Eggs are adhesive and laid among fine plants. It tolerates low oxygen but is vulnerable to pesticide pulses.

A small Indo-Pacific tonguefish inhabiting sandy estuarine flats and lower rivers. Extremely laterally compressed, it buries in sediment and feeds on tiny crustaceans and worms. Spawning and larval drift are tied to tidal cycles. Sensitive to dredging and estuary infilling.

The Mexican stoneroller of arid western Mexico and SW USA headwaters. With cartilaginous scraping ridges, it grazes algae on cobbles, often creating “grazing halos.” It schools in shallow riffles and spawns over clean gravel in spring. Groundwater depletion and fine sediment are primary stressors.

Yaqui sucker endemic to Sonora–Arizona drainages. Prefers deep pools and runs with moderate flow, sifting benthos and detritus. Spring spawning occurs over gravel bars; adults migrate within pool–riffle complexes. Water withdrawals and prolonged drought constrain recovery.

Swordspine snook of the tropical W Atlantic frequenting mangrove creeks and estuaries. A nocturnal ambush predator, it strikes small fishes and shrimp along structure. Adults move seasonally between estuaries and nearshore surf zones. Nursery loss from mangrove clearing reduces recruitment.

Fat snook distributed from the Caribbean to SE Brazil. It uses mangrove–lagoon mosaics as nurseries, shifting offshore as it grows. Protandrous hermaphrodite populations require size structure for successful reproduction. Coastal development and gillnet effort affect stocks.

Cuban snook localized around Cuba and nearby Antilles. Ecology parallels congeners: crepuscular predator, estuarine juvenile phase, nearshore adult foraging. Its restricted range heightens risk to localized habitat damage. Bycatch regulations and mangrove protections benefit the species.

Spined loach described from Anatolian streams with sandy backwaters. It is crepuscular, sifting fine sediments for chironomids and microcrustaceans. Seasonal hydrology drives short breeding windows with adhesive eggs under pebbles. Diversions that desiccate margins imperil populations.

Endemic to Lake Ohrid basin (N. Macedonia/Albania), occupying quiet littoral zones over sand and fine gravel. Slender, mottled body and subterminal barbels suit benthic foraging. It spawns in late spring among stones and macrophytes. Shoreline modification and invasive fishes are the main concerns.

Freckled hardyhead from northern Australia’s spring-fed creeks and floodplain pools. Forms tight shoals picking zooplankton and algae; freckling intensifies in adults. Multiple small spawning bouts occur through the warm season. Groundwater extraction threatens spring refugia.

Dearborn’s pupfish inhabits hypersaline ponds and coastal lagoons of the southern Caribbean. Highly tolerant of salinity and temperature swings, it grazes algae and invertebrates near the surface. Small, isolated demes exhibit rapid life cycles. Habitat filling and invasive poeciliids are risks.

Endemic to the Nazas–Aguanaval basin (Mexico), occupying springs and slow, alkaline channels. Short-lived and fecund, it spawns repeatedly in warm months. Diet is primarily algal with supplemental micro-invertebrates. Spring capture and aquifer depletion caused severe range contractions.

Cuban pupfish of hypersaline coastal lagoons and salinas. Robust jaws scrape filamentous algae and diatoms; males defend small territories. Eggs adhere to vegetation and shells in very shallow water. Coastal works and pollution can rapidly degrade tiny habitats.

The Okaloosa darter, micro-endemic to six Florida Panhandle streams with clear, sandy riffles. Adults bury shallowly in shifting sand and feed on microcrustaceans; spawning occurs in spring. Intensive restoration (culvert removal, erosion control) improved status recently. It remains sensitive to sediment inputs.

Common galaxias of SE Australia inhabits cool creeks, bogs, and small lakes. Opportunistic insectivore with nocturnal activity; juveniles use woody debris for cover. Some populations are land-locked; others are amphidromous. Trout predation and catchment clearing reduce upland populations.

Spotted galaxias of Tasmania and southern mainland Australia, often amphidromous with estuarine larval phase. Adults occupy shaded, boulder-lined streams and forest lakes. Distinct leopard-like spotting provides camouflage. Weirs and trout introductions disrupt migrations and refuges.

Canterbury galaxias (NZ South Island), a non-migratory upland species. It prefers cool, shallow riffles and feeds on mayflies and midges. Fragmented by irrigation takes and trout, many subpopulations are tiny. Predator-free fencing and fish passage work aid recovery.

Wadi Garra from Oman/UAE inhabits clear, seasonal wadis over bedrock and gravel. A mental adhesive disc allows station-holding in current while scraping algae. Populations survive droughts in bedrock pools. Over-abstraction and flash-flood scouring alter refuges.

Lake Sentani rainbowfish with high scale counts and orange-to-gold males. Occupies weedy littoral zones and slow inlets, schooling over submerged wood. It feeds on zooplankton and insect drift; egg-scatterer among vegetation. Exotics and shoreline siltation have reduced wild fish.

Small African sabrefish relative from swift Congo tributaries. Lateral-line morphology and streamlined body suit high-energy runs where it picks drifting invertebrates. Schooling improves station-holding and predator avoidance. Logging and artisanal mining elevate turbidity.

Speckled chub of the Mississippi–Rio Grande basins, favoring broad sandy rivers. It is a pelagic broadcast spawner with semi-buoyant eggs adapted to long drift. Barbels and inferior mouth target benthic insects. Channelization and flow regulation reduce egg transport and habitat.

Sturgeon chub specializing on swift, shallow, turbid prairie rivers. Keel-like body and enlarged pectorals aid station-holding. It forages on aquatic insect larvae; eggs are semi-buoyant. Dams that dampen peak flows and trap sediment imperil recruitment.

Aru Islands rainbowfish inhabiting rainforest creeks with leaf-tannin staining. Males develop rich copper and emerald hues; groups browse microcrustaceans at mid-water. Adhesive eggs are laid daily among fine roots. Logging and drainage threaten headwater stability.

“Exquisite” rainbowfish of northern Australia’s sandstone streams. Clear, fast runs and plunge pools host shoals that graze periphyton and zooplankton. Males show striking iridescent lateral bands in breeding condition. Water extraction and feral animals degrade riparian cover.

Murray–Darling rainbowfish common in lowland rivers, billabongs, and weir pools. Omnivorous and schooling, it thrives in warm, vegetated margins and spawns repeatedly in summer. It is a key prey item for native predators. Cold-water pollution and carp-driven turbidity reduce nursery habitat.

The dwarf neon rainbowfish from New Guinea’s Mamberamo system, celebrated for electric blue males and ruby fins. Inhabits clear forest streams with moderate current. Continuous trickle-spawner with adhesive eggs among fine plants. Over-collection and logging-related siltation threaten wild stocks.

New Guinea rainbowfish of swampy lowland creeks and flooded forest. Feeds on microcrustaceans and insect larvae near the surface; forms small shoals. Breeds year-round in warm water with daily egg deposition. Peat swamp drainage and invasive fishes are key risks.

Bridle shiner from Atlantic slope lowlands (USA/Canada) inhabits vegetated backwaters and slow creeks. It grazes periphyton and picks small invertebrates among macrophytes. Highly sensitive to turbidity and flow alteration, it has declined across its range. Wetland loss is the principal driver.

Minnow tigerfish of the Zambezi–Limpopo systems, an agile mid-water predator in clear rivers. Juveniles school; adults chase small fishes and large insects in runs and pools. It undertakes seasonal migrations to spawn on clean gravels. Sand abstraction and barriers disrupt life cycles.

Oregon chub endemic to the Willamette Valley, USA, favoring slack off-channel ponds with dense vegetation. Short-lived and fecund, it feeds on zooplankton and aquatic insects. Intensive habitat restoration led to ESA delisting—an American conservation success. Persistence still depends on floodplain connectivity.

Channel Darter native to the Mekong basin; large, migratory, and omnivorous. Wild fish move seasonally with flood pulses; aquaculture now supplies most market demand. Wild stocks are affected by dams that truncate migrations and sand mining that alters channels. It remains a key food fish regionally.

The channel darter is a small percid native to eastern North America, occurring in sandy or gravel runs of rivers and nearshore lake habitats. It feeds on insect larvae and small benthic invertebrates, using camouflage to blend into the substrate. Spawning occurs in spring, with males guarding small territories in shallow riffles. Siltation, damming, and invasive species have reduced many populations, making it a conservation concern.

A small pimelodid catfish found in the Paraná and Uruguay basins of South America. It is nocturnal, hiding under debris or in burrows during the day, and feeds on aquatic insects and worms at night. Its long barbels aid foraging in turbid waters. Although widespread, it is vulnerable to habitat alteration from dams and pollution.

The estuarine pipefish endemic to South Africa’s coastal estuaries and lagoons. It lives among eelgrass beds and mangrove roots, feeding on small crustaceans. Males carry developing embryos in a brood pouch until hatching. Coastal development and estuary pollution pose major risks.

A killifish endemic to Cuba, inhabiting freshwater streams, ponds, and swamps with dense vegetation. It feeds on aquatic insects and small invertebrates, often near the water’s surface. Males are more brightly colored than females, especially during courtship. Localized habitat loss and pollution threaten populations.

A small cobitid loach restricted to clear, gravelly rivers of northern Italy. It is nocturnal and feeds on insect larvae and small benthic organisms by burrowing in sand. Spawning occurs in spring, with eggs deposited among gravels. Dams and agricultural runoff have caused significant declines.

Known as the Kashmir snow trout, it is found in cold, fast-flowing rivers and lakes of the Himalayas. It feeds mainly on algae and benthic invertebrates, scraping food with its horny jaws. It is an important fishery resource in Kashmir, though overharvest and habitat degradation threaten stocks. Climate change and glacier retreat further stress its range.

A cyprinid endemic to Iberian rivers (Portugal and Spain), often inhabiting fast-flowing, rocky streams. It is omnivorous, feeding on algae, insects, and detritus, and shows seasonal shifts in diet. It plays a role in freshwater food webs as both grazer and prey. Water pollution and droughts threaten riverine populations.

A rare characin from Central America, recorded in rivers with slow-moving or still waters. It feeds on aquatic insects and small crustaceans. Little is known about its life history, but it likely forms schools during the wet season. Habitat degradation and pollution are suspected threats.

A climbing catfish found in Andean streams of Colombia and Ecuador. It uses modified pelvic fins and a sucker-like mouth to cling to rocks and even climb waterfalls. It feeds on algae and insect larvae in high-gradient streams. Deforestation and sedimentation threaten these sensitive habitats.

Another Andean catfish species occurring in Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru. It prefers cold, clear mountain streams and feeds on periphyton and aquatic insects. Its climbing ability allows access to habitats less available to competitors. Mining and watershed degradation are increasing pressures.

A hillstream loach from the Western Ghats, India, inhabiting torrential streams with rocky substrates. Its flattened body and adhesive mouth allow it to cling to stones in fast currents. It grazes on algae and detritus. Hydroelectric development and deforestation threaten its restricted range.

A characin widely distributed in Central and East Africa, occurring in rivers, lakes, and floodplains. It forms schools and feeds opportunistically on insects, plankton, and small fish. It is ecologically important as prey for larger piscivores. Overfishing and habitat degradation impact some populations.

Found in Lake Victoria and surrounding rivers, this species inhabits shallow inshore zones. It is a fast-growing shoaling fish that feeds on insects and crustaceans. It is important in artisanal fisheries. Declines have been noted due to Nile perch predation and water quality deterioration.

The Caspian sprat is a small pelagic fish endemic to the Caspian Sea. It forms large schools, feeding on zooplankton and serving as prey for commercial species like sturgeons. Spawning occurs offshore in spring and summer. Pollution, invasive species, and overfishing have reduced stocks.

The Darling River hardyhead of inland Australia, found in small streams and waterholes. It is omnivorous, feeding on algae, insects, and zooplankton. Populations fluctuate greatly with drought and flooding cycles. Water diversion and invasive species such as Gambusia threaten its persistence.

The purple-spotted hardyhead of northern Australia inhabits rivers, floodplains, and billabongs. It is shoaling and feeds on algae, detritus, and zooplankton. Distinctive purplish body spots are more vivid in breeding males. Habitat alteration from grazing and water extraction impacts populations.

Known as the fly-specked hardyhead, common in coastal rivers and lagoons of northern Australia. It tolerates a wide salinity range, from fresh to brackish. It feeds on small insects and algae, spawning multiple times in summer. It remains abundant but is sensitive to water quality decline.

The blackmast hardyhead occurs in Australia’s inland rivers, forming large shoals in turbid channels. It is an omnivore, feeding on algae, zooplankton, and detritus. It spawns in shallow vegetated zones during floods. River regulation and invasive carp compete for resources.

A small cyprinid endemic to Kerala, India, usually inhabiting shaded hill streams. It feeds on periphyton and insect larvae. It is rare and has a very restricted range, making it vulnerable to habitat destruction. Agricultural runoff and stream modification are key threats.

A killifish distributed across West Africa in forest streams, swamps, and floodplains. It is surface-oriented, feeding on insects and mosquito larvae. Its striking coloration makes it popular in the aquarium trade. Deforestation and swamp drainage threaten natural populations.

A recently described galaxias from Tasmania, restricted to cool, clear mountain streams. It feeds on aquatic insects and crustaceans. As a non-migratory species, it is highly vulnerable to predation by introduced trout. Its limited distribution increases its conservation concern.

Flathead galaxias of southeast Australia inhabits slow streams and floodplain wetlands. It feeds on insect larvae and small crustaceans, and breeds in late winter. It is now rare due to wetland drainage and competition with introduced fish. Conservation efforts include captive breeding and reintroduction.

The ornate galaxias is native to Victoria, Australia, and occupies cool upland creeks. Its patterned body provides camouflage against cobbles. It spawns in spring, with adhesive eggs deposited under stones. Habitat fragmentation and trout predation are significant threats.

Known as the melon barb, it is a colorful cyprinid from the Western Ghats, India. It inhabits clear, fast streams and feeds on algae and small insects. It is widely kept in aquaria for its red and black striped pattern. Wild populations are declining from deforestation and water extraction.

The elongate tigerfish of African rivers, including the Nile and Niger systems. It is a powerful predator with sharp teeth, feeding mainly on smaller fish. It plays a key ecological role as a top predator. Overfishing and damming have affected local stocks.

A cold-water loach native to Japan, inhabiting mountain streams with sandy bottoms. It burrows into substrate during winter, a unique adaptation among loaches. It feeds on insect larvae and worms. Stream channelization and pollution threaten local populations.

The Tasmanian whitebait, a galaxiid that migrates between rivers and the sea. Adults spawn in estuaries, and larvae drift to marine waters before returning. Once a commercial fishery, it collapsed due to overharvest and habitat loss. It is now protected, though still vulnerable.

A seasonal killifish native to ephemeral pools of Zambia’s Kafue Basin. It completes its life cycle in months, with drought-resistant eggs that survive dry seasons. Males are brilliantly colored, while females are cryptic. Habitat loss from agriculture and climate variability threaten its survival.

A stone loach endemic to Balkan rivers in Bulgaria and Greece. It inhabits riffles and gravel beds with clean, fast-flowing water. It feeds on benthic invertebrates such as insect larvae and small mollusks. Pollution and water extraction have reduced its habitat quality.

A small minnow endemic to southern France, restricted to a few rivers. It inhabits cool, clear streams and feeds on invertebrates and algae. Its restricted range makes it highly vulnerable to droughts and water pollution. Conservation action is needed to maintain its habitats.

A cyprinid from Myanmar and Thailand, inhabiting slow-flowing forest streams and ponds. It is peaceful, shoaling, and feeds on small insects and plankton. Its bright coloration makes it common in aquaria. Logging and agricultural runoff reduce water quality in its habitats.

The Tasmanian smelt, a small schooling fish inhabiting estuaries and rivers. It is surface-oriented, feeding on plankton and insect larvae. Spawning occurs in spring, with larvae drifting downstream. Water abstraction and invasive trout impact populations.

A rudd species restricted to Italian lakes and slow rivers. It is herbivorous, feeding mainly on macrophytes and algae. Brightly colored fins make it distinctive in clear waters. Introductions of exotic fishes and eutrophication threaten its survival.

The Kimberley archerfish of northern Australia, inhabiting clear rivers and tidal creeks. Like other archerfish, it shoots jets of water to knock insects from vegetation. Juveniles use mangrove nurseries, while adults occupy rocky pools. It is sensitive to altered flows and mining impacts.

A gudgeon endemic to Papua New Guinea, found in clear upland streams. It feeds on aquatic insects and crustaceans, staying close to the substrate. Males guard nests under stones during breeding. Deforestation and mining sediment threaten headwaters.

The olive perchlet from Australia inhabits rivers, lakes, and estuaries. It is small and translucent, forming shoals that feed on plankton and insect larvae. Once widespread, it has declined severely due to habitat loss and invasive predators. Recovery programs have reintroduced it into restored wetlands.

A Central American cichlid inhabiting rivers of Mexico and Guatemala. It is omnivorous, feeding on algae, detritus, and small invertebrates. Males develop long fin extensions during breeding and guard territories aggressively. Deforestation and agricultural pollution threaten rivers it inhabits.

A tonguefish native to Indo-Pacific estuaries, living on sandy and muddy substrates. It buries itself to ambush small invertebrates and worms. Its flat body and mottled coloration provide excellent camouflage. Coastal dredging and estuarine modification affect populations.

Known as the Rio Grande sucker, endemic to tributaries in New Mexico. It feeds on algae and detritus, using fleshy lips to scrape rocks. Spawning takes place in shallow riffles during spring. Water withdrawals and habitat degradation have made it rare.

A loach endemic to Morocco, occurring in small rivers and streams with sandy bottoms. It is cryptic and burrows into sediment by day, emerging to feed on insect larvae at night. It has a highly fragmented distribution. Agricultural pollution and water abstraction endanger it.

The Klamath sculpin from Oregon and northern California inhabits rocky streams and lakeshores. It is benthic, feeding on aquatic insects and crustaceans. It spawns in spring, with males guarding eggs under stones. Altered flow regimes and introduced species are concerns.

A small killifish endemic to Cuba, occupying swamps, ponds, and slow streams. It feeds on insect larvae and detritus, helping control mosquito populations. Males show bright colors and courtship displays. Habitat loss and invasive species like Gambusia threaten it.

The proserpine shiner of Mexico inhabits clear, spring-fed streams with rocky substrates. It is a small schooling fish that feeds on insects and algae. Its distribution is highly restricted, making it vulnerable to water extraction. It is considered endangered.

The spotted darter of the Ohio River drainage inhabits swift, rocky riffles. It is colorful, with males displaying bright orange and blue patterns during spawning. It feeds on aquatic insects and spawns in gravel crevices. Habitat fragmentation has reduced its range.

Endemic to Hispaniola, this mosquitofish occupies rivers, ditches, and lakes. It is a surface-feeding livebearer that consumes mosquito larvae and algae. Females give birth to multiple broods annually. Deforestation and wetland drainage affect populations.

Found in Cuba and the Bahamas, inhabiting vegetated streams and brackish lagoons. It feeds on insects and detritus, reproducing viviparously. It is hardy and adaptable but threatened by pollution and invasive predators.

A Cuban livebearer inhabiting freshwater streams and coastal lagoons. It is opportunistic, feeding on insects and algae. Its tolerance of varied salinity allows it to thrive in disturbed habitats. Habitat modification and introduced species pose risks.

Known as the Tex-Mex gambusia, native to the Rio Grande basin. It lives in vegetated margins of springs and streams, feeding on insects and plankton. Its restricted distribution has made it vulnerable, and it is now considered endangered. Conservation relies on spring habitat protection.

A freshwater goby native to Papua New Guinea, typically found in rivers and streams with sandy or muddy substrates. It feeds on small crustaceans and insect larvae and is adapted to both clear and turbid waters. Its ecological role is significant in maintaining aquatic food chains.

Endemic to Papua New Guinea, this goby inhabits streams with moderate flow and rocky substrates. It uses camouflage to blend with the substrate and feeds mainly on benthic invertebrates. It is considered important in balancing stream ecosystems.

Found in fast-flowing streams, this goby clings to rocks using fused pelvic fins. It consumes aquatic insects and small crustaceans drifting in the current. Its presence indicates clean, well-oxygenated waters.

Known as the common bully, it is one of New Zealand’s most widespread freshwater fish. It thrives in lakes and rivers, feeding on insect larvae and crustaceans, while serving as prey for larger fish and birds. It plays a vital role in freshwater ecosystems.

A Lake Victoria cichlid that is part of the adaptive Haplochromine radiation. It has specialized jaw morphology for scraping algae and feeding on invertebrates. Populations have been threatened by the introduction of Nile perch and habitat degradation.

A gudgeon native to Papua New Guinea, often found in streams with sandy or rocky substrates. It is benthic, feeding on aquatic insect larvae, worms, and small crustaceans. Its adaptability to varying habitats highlights its ecological resilience.

Also called the beautiful mogurnda, it is endemic to Queensland, Australia. It prefers clear, vegetated streams and is an opportunistic feeder. It is popular in the aquarium trade due to its bright coloration.

A small goby inhabiting Southeast Asian freshwater and estuarine systems. It lives in shallow waters with vegetation, feeding on zooplankton and detritus. Its ecological importance lies in serving as prey for larger predators.
A catfish found in South and Southeast Asia, common in rivers and reservoirs. It is carnivorous, feeding on insects, crustaceans, and small fish. It also holds value in local fisheries.

A rare sleeper goby from Papua New Guinea, inhabiting sluggish rivers and swampy areas. It preys on small fish and crustaceans, with a distribution limited to specific habitats. Its rarity makes it sensitive to environmental change.

A cichlid native to West Africa, adapted to fast-flowing river habitats. It grazes on algae and invertebrates and clings to rocks using strong fins. It helps regulate algal growth in river ecosystems.
Endemic to southern Mexico, this cichlid inhabits rocky rivers. It exhibits advanced parental care, guarding both eggs and fry. Its vibrant appearance has made it a valued aquarium fish.

A small fish restricted to brackish and freshwater habitats of New Guinea. It feeds on plankton and small invertebrates in river deltas and estuaries. Its narrow distribution makes it vulnerable to habitat pollution.

A halfbeak from Southeast Asia inhabiting brackish and coastal waters. It is surface-dwelling and feeds on insects and plant matter. Its elongated lower jaw helps it snap at food items drifting on the surface.

A gudgeon from Papua New Guinea, inhabiting clear freshwater streams with rocky substrates. It feeds mainly on aquatic insects, worms, and small crustaceans. Its limited range makes it vulnerable to habitat degradation caused by logging and mining activities.

Endemic to Papua New Guinea, this gudgeon thrives in shallow streams and river margins. It has a benthic lifestyle, foraging along the substrate for invertebrates. Restricted to localized habitats, it is considered at risk from water pollution.

A small cyprinid distributed in India and Sri Lanka. It inhabits ponds, rivers, and irrigation canals, feeding on plankton and detritus. It is often used as a forage fish in aquaculture and local fisheries.

A loricariid catfish from Central America, found in rivers with strong currents. It uses its sucker mouth to graze algae from rocks and submerged wood. Its armored body and nocturnal habits provide protection against predators.

Native to Ecuador, this armored catfish inhabits Andean streams with rocky beds. It is herbivorous, scraping algae and biofilm for food. The species contributes to stream ecology by controlling algal growth.

A South American freshwater fish inhabiting rivers with moderate currents. It is a detritivore, feeding on organic matter and algae. Its ecological role is linked to nutrient cycling within river systems.

A dwarf cichlid from the Amazon basin, found in slow-moving, tannin-rich waters. It is territorial, with males defending small areas during breeding. Popular in the aquarium trade, it requires specific water chemistry to thrive.

A catfish native to Andean streams, adapted to fast-flowing, oxygen-rich environments. Its sucker mouth allows it to cling to rocks in torrents. It feeds on aquatic invertebrates and plays a role in stream food webs.

A characin from South America inhabiting rivers and floodplains. It is omnivorous, consuming insects, algae, and plant debris. Like other Astyanax, it is important in local food chains and is resilient to habitat changes.

Endemic to Panama, this small characin lives in freshwater rivers and streams. It feeds opportunistically on insects and detritus. Its restricted distribution makes it potentially vulnerable to habitat alteration.

Found in Nicaraguan freshwater systems, this species adapts to lakes and rivers. It is omnivorous, feeding on insects, algae, and small crustaceans. It is locally important as both forage and aquarium fish.

A species native to Panama, inhabiting rivers with moderate flow. It feeds on insects, worms, and plant matter, making it ecologically versatile. Its adaptability has allowed it to persist despite localized environmental changes.

A silverside native to Central America, occurring in freshwater and brackish waters. It forms schools and feeds on plankton and small insects. It contributes to food webs as prey for larger fish and birds.

A cichlid from South America, inhabiting rivers and streams with dense vegetation. It is omnivorous and shows strong parental care, with pairs guarding their offspring. Its adaptability makes it suitable for aquariums.

Closely related to A. muriae, this cichlid inhabits similar freshwater habitats in South America. It has a broad diet of algae, insects, and detritus. The species is recognized for its tolerance to varying water quality.

A large bagrid catfish native to East Africa, found in lakes and rivers such as Lake Victoria. It is a nocturnal predator that feeds on smaller fish and crustaceans. Valued as a food fish, it plays an important role in local fisheries but faces pressure from overfishing and habitat degradation.

A South American knifefish inhabiting slow-moving rivers and floodplains. It uses electric signals for communication and navigation, especially in murky waters. Feeding on insect larvae and small invertebrates, it is ecologically important in tropical floodplain food webs.

A characin from Colombia and Venezuela, common in fast-flowing rivers. It is omnivorous, consuming fruits, seeds, and insects, and thus contributes to seed dispersal. Its ecological role links terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems.

Found in Central American rivers, this characin thrives in clear, fast-flowing waters. It is omnivorous, feeding on fruits, insects, and algae, and is an important prey item for larger fish. Populations are threatened by deforestation and dam construction.
A small characin native to Ecuadorian streams and rivers. It feeds mainly on aquatic insects and detritus. While not commercially significant, it is ecologically important as prey for larger species.

A banjo catfish from South America, living in sandy or muddy river bottoms. Its flattened body provides camouflage, while it scavenges detritus and small invertebrates. It plays a role in nutrient recycling in river ecosystems.

A North American minnow that inhabits streams and small rivers with gravel bottoms. It is herbivorous, scraping algae from rocks with its specialized jaws. It is ecologically important as a primary consumer in freshwater systems.

Endemic to Morocco, this cyprinid inhabits rivers and streams with rocky substrates. It feeds on algae, aquatic plants, and small invertebrates. Due to its restricted range, it is vulnerable to habitat loss and water extraction.

Known as the desert sucker, it is native to the Colorado River basin in the U.S. It thrives in swift-flowing streams and grazes algae and detritus from rocks. It is tolerant of fluctuating water levels but is impacted by habitat modification.

Also called the bluehead sucker, this species is distributed in the upper Colorado and Green River systems. It has a specialized head shape for scraping algae from rocks. Populations are threatened by water diversion and invasive species.

The flannelmouth sucker inhabits the Colorado River and its tributaries. It grows relatively large and feeds on algae, detritus, and benthic invertebrates. Conservation programs monitor its populations due to declining habitats.
A giant predatory catfish from the Amazon basin. It lives in deep river channels and preys on fish and large aquatic organisms. It is less studied but noted for its ecological role as a top predator.
A small darter-like characin native to South America. It inhabits clear, fast-flowing streams and feeds on aquatic insects. Its cryptic coloration helps it blend with gravel substrates.

Another small characin found in South American streams, adapted to benthic living. It feeds on insect larvae and plays an important role in controlling aquatic invertebrate populations. It is sensitive to water quality changes.
A small African cyprinid inhabiting rivers and floodplains. It feeds on plankton and small insects and often forms large schools. It provides food for many larger fishes and aquatic birds.

A rainbowfish from New Guinea, living in clear, fast-flowing streams. It is noted for its bright colors and active schooling behavior. Its popularity in the aquarium trade is balanced by concerns about habitat degradation.

A cichlid from rivers in Central America, often associated with rocky habitats. It is omnivorous and shows strong parental care, guarding eggs and fry. It is valued in aquaculture and the aquarium trade.

A small fish endemic to Gorgona Island off Colombia. It inhabits freshwater streams and has a restricted range, making it highly vulnerable. Its biology is poorly studied, but it likely feeds on small invertebrates.
A small armored catfish from Brazil, living in streams and floodplain habitats. It feeds on insect larvae, worms, and detritus along the substrate. Popular in aquariums, it is peaceful and hardy.

A freshwater sculpin found in European streams with rocky substrates. It is benthic, feeding on insect larvae and small crustaceans. Its sensitivity to pollution makes it an indicator of water quality.

A hardy rainbowfish from New Guinea, inhabiting rivers and lagoons. It is omnivorous, feeding on algae and small invertebrates. It adapts well to different habitats but is locally threatened by habitat alteration.

Native to New Guinea, this species lives in freshwater streams and lagoons. It consumes algae, detritus, and small aquatic invertebrates. It plays an important role in local food webs and is popular in the aquarium trade.

A South American pike cichlid inhabiting rivers with rocky or sandy bottoms. It is predatory, feeding on smaller fish and crustaceans. Its elongated body and ambush behavior make it a top mid-level predator.

Another South American pike cichlid adapted to riverine habitats. It is piscivorous and territorial, often hiding among submerged logs. It has ecological importance in regulating smaller fish populations.
A small cichlid from Central America, inhabiting streams and lagoons. It exhibits biparental care and is aggressive when guarding offspring. Its adaptability makes it popular in aquaria.
A small characin endemic to Brazilian streams. It feeds on insects, algae, and organic detritus. Though not commercially important, it plays a role in nutrient cycling.

A small cyprinid from the Rio Grande basin in the U.S. and Mexico. It inhabits clear streams with gravel beds, feeding on algae and detritus. Its populations are declining due to habitat fragmentation.
A large African characin found in river systems across Central Africa. It is herbivorous, feeding on aquatic vegetation and algae. It is targeted by local fisheries for food.
Another large African characin, distributed across the Congo Basin. It has an elongated snout adapted for browsing aquatic plants. It is an important food fish but faces pressure from overfishing.
A small cyprinid found in southern African rivers and lakes. It feeds on plankton and forms schools, serving as prey for larger fishes. It is important in maintaining aquatic food chains.
A small barb widely distributed in African streams and rivers. It feeds on aquatic insects and algae. It is ecologically significant as prey for larger fish and aquatic birds.
Endemic to Ghana, this barb inhabits rivers with rocky and sandy substrates. It feeds on insect larvae and organic matter. It is considered vulnerable due to habitat disturbance and pollution.
A small cyprinid from African rivers, recognizable by its distinctive coloration. It grazes on algae and small invertebrates, playing a role in nutrient cycling. Populations are stable but localized.
Found in East African streams, it prefers clear, well-oxygenated waters. It feeds on aquatic insects and small crustaceans. It is ecologically important in supporting local food webs.
A Colombian barb inhabiting rivers and streams of the Magdalena Basin. It feeds on insects, algae, and detritus. It is locally significant in small-scale fisheries.
A widespread African species living in rivers, lakes, and streams. It is omnivorous and adapts to a wide range of habitats. Its broad distribution makes it ecologically resilient.
Endemic to Lake Victoria, this small barb lives in shallow nearshore waters. It feeds on algae, insect larvae, and plankton. Its restricted range makes it sensitive to habitat changes.
A southern African species inhabiting rivers with clear, rocky substrates. It is omnivorous and provides food for predatory fish. It is relatively common and not currently threatened.
A deep-water barb from Lake Victoria, feeding on zooplankton and insect larvae. It has declined in numbers due to Nile perch introduction but persists in refugia.
A killifish from West Africa, living in small streams and swamps. It feeds on insects at the water surface and displays striking coloration. It is occasionally kept in aquaria.
A rare catfish from South America inhabiting deep rivers. It has specialized adaptations for benthic living, feeding on detritus and small organisms. Its biology remains poorly studied.
A South American cichlid inhabiting rivers and floodplains. It is a substrate-sifter, taking in sand and filtering out edible material. It is valued in aquariums for its striking appearance.
A poeciliid fish from Cuba, living in freshwater streams and ponds. It feeds on algae, detritus, and small invertebrates. Its adaptability makes it a resilient species in disturbed habitats.

A small poeciliid fish endemic to Cuba, commonly found in shallow freshwater ponds, ditches, and streams. It is livebearing and feeds on algae, detritus, and small aquatic invertebrates. Its metallic sheen gives it ornamental appeal, though it is mostly studied for ecology and evolutionary biology.

Another Cuban poeciliid inhabiting slow-flowing rivers and wetlands. It has a preference for vegetated habitats where it grazes on algae and microorganisms. As a livebearer, it is studied for reproductive strategies and population dynamics.

A goby from Papua New Guinea found in shallow rivers with sandy or muddy bottoms. It preys on aquatic invertebrates and small fish, contributing to benthic food webs. Its limited range makes it sensitive to habitat disturbances.

Native to freshwater habitats in New Guinea, this goby prefers vegetated stream margins. It is carnivorous, feeding on insect larvae and small crustaceans. Its biology is not well-documented but it is considered ecologically important in stream systems.

A European gudgeon species restricted to central Italy. It inhabits clear, stony rivers and streams, feeding on benthic invertebrates. Its limited range and habitat sensitivity place it at some conservation risk.

Distributed across Central and Eastern Europe, this gudgeon inhabits cool rivers with rocky bottoms. It feeds on insect larvae and detritus and is an important prey for larger fish. Its presence indicates good water quality.

A cyprinid native to Central Asia, found in cold, fast-flowing rivers and high-altitude lakes. It feeds on algae, periphyton, and small benthic invertebrates. It is well adapted to harsh mountain environments but threatened by climate change.

A goby species from East Asia inhabiting rivers, estuaries, and coastal waters. It feeds on small crustaceans and insects and tolerates a wide range of salinities. It contributes to estuarine and freshwater food webs.

A brightly colored cichlid endemic to Lake Victoria, often found near rocky shores. Males display vibrant yellow coloration during breeding, while females are more subdued. Populations have been reduced by competition and predation from Nile perch.

A small characin distributed in Panama and Colombia. It inhabits rivers and streams, feeding on insects and plant matter. Its ecological role is as both a consumer of terrestrial inputs and prey for larger species.

A predatory characin from South America, related to the well-known “trahiras.” It lives in rivers and lakes, feeding on fish and large invertebrates. As a top predator, it helps regulate prey populations.

A loricariid catfish native to northeastern Brazil. It clings to rocks with its sucker mouth and scrapes algae and detritus for food. This species is ecologically important for controlling algal growth in rivers.

A livebearing fish native to Uruguay and southern Brazil, inhabiting ponds and slow streams. It feeds on algae and invertebrates and has internal fertilization with distinct sexual dimorphism. It is resilient to environmental fluctuations.

A cyprinid widespread in southern Africa, inhabiting large rivers and floodplains. It feeds by scraping algae and detritus from submerged surfaces. Its abundance makes it an important fish in local fisheries.

A goby from New Guinea, inhabiting clear, fast-flowing mountain streams. Its fused pelvic fins allow it to cling to rocks in strong currents. It feeds on insect larvae and is a key component of upland stream ecosystems.
A cyprinid from Central Asia inhabiting rivers and lakes. It is omnivorous, feeding on invertebrates, algae, and detritus. Its populations are impacted by water extraction and habitat loss.

A small cyprinid native to Italy and the Balkans, inhabiting lakes and slow rivers. It feeds on plankton, algae, and small invertebrates. Though not commercially important, it is ecologically relevant as prey.
A poeciliid fish endemic to Hispaniola, inhabiting brackish lagoons and streams. It is livebearing and feeds on algae and detritus. It is vulnerable due to habitat degradation in the Caribbean.
Endemic to Algeria, inhabiting rivers with rocky substrates. It feeds on algae and invertebrates and shows seasonal spawning migrations. Its restricted range makes it conservation-dependent.

Another North African barbel, distributed in Tunisia and Algeria. It inhabits rivers and lakes, feeding on benthic invertebrates and detritus. Populations face pressure from water regulation and pollution.
Found only in the Chelif River basin of Algeria. It inhabits freshwater rivers and feeds on invertebrates and algae. Its highly localized distribution makes it vulnerable to extinction.
Native to Morocco, inhabiting rivers and streams with variable flows. It is omnivorous and migratory during spawning seasons. Conservation measures are needed due to water scarcity.
Endemic to North Africa, found in Moroccan rivers. It feeds on benthic invertebrates and algae. Restricted distribution and overexploitation have raised conservation concerns.
Found in Moroccan river basins, inhabiting moderate-flow freshwater habitats. It grazes on algae and detritus and supports local food chains. Its survival is threatened by human water use.
Endemic to rivers of northern Morocco, adapted to clear, rocky streams. It feeds on algae and aquatic insects. Its restricted range places it at high conservation concern.
A barbel from Algeria, inhabiting rivers with gravelly beds. It is omnivorous, feeding on algae and benthic organisms. Its populations are poorly studied but may be affected by habitat loss.
Native to Moroccan rivers, it thrives in flowing freshwater ecosystems. It feeds on aquatic vegetation and invertebrates. Conservation actions are needed due to water stress in its habitats.

An African mormyrid found in West African rivers. It uses electric organ discharges for navigation and communication. Feeding on insects and small invertebrates, it is a key component of riverine ecosystems.
A cichlid native to Central America, inhabiting rocky river habitats. It is territorial and shows strong parental care. It is locally known in the aquarium trade.
A small African characin found in rivers and floodplains. It feeds on insects and small crustaceans. It plays an important role as prey for larger fish and birds.
Distributed across West Africa, this characin inhabits freshwater rivers and lakes. It feeds mainly on zooplankton and insects. It contributes to nutrient cycling and food webs in its habitats.
A small catfish from Brazil, inhabiting streams with sandy or rocky beds. It is nocturnal and feeds on insect larvae and detritus. Its cryptic behavior provides camouflage against predators.
A killifish found in the Nile basin, inhabiting shallow streams and floodplains. It feeds on mosquito larvae and other small insects. It is ecologically important in controlling insect populations.
A mormyrid from African rivers, using weak electric discharges for navigation. It feeds on insect larvae, worms, and small crustaceans. Its large eyes help in foraging in dimly lit waters.
A cyprinid from Southeast Asia, inhabiting clear streams with rocky substrates. It feeds on algae, detritus, and aquatic invertebrates. It is common in local fisheries.
A small bagrid catfish distributed in South Asia. It inhabits rivers and streams and feeds on insects and worms. Its small size makes it less commercially valuable but ecologically significant.

Native to Sri Lanka, this catfish lives in rivers and floodplains. It is carnivorous, feeding on insects, crustaceans, and small fish. Its restricted distribution places it under conservation concern.
A tiny catfish from Borneo, inhabiting forest streams. It is nocturnal and feeds on insect larvae and detritus. Its small size and cryptic habits make it difficult to study.
A little-known cyprinid from Southeast Asia. It inhabits rivers and feeds on plankton and small invertebrates. Its biology is poorly documented.
A rare characin from Brazil, inhabiting small forest streams. It has a slender body and feeds on insects and detritus. It is occasionally kept by aquarists.
A mudfish endemic to the Chatham Islands of New Zealand. It inhabits swamps and drains that dry seasonally, surviving through burrowing. It is highly endangered due to its extremely limited range.
A catfish from New Guinea, inhabiting slow rivers and floodplains. It is benthic, feeding on fish, insects, and crustaceans. Its biology is still not well studied.
Another New Guinea catfish, adapted to slow, turbid rivers. It is predatory and forms part of local fisheries. Habitat modification threatens its long-term survival.
A halfbeak native to Sulawesi, Indonesia. It lives in freshwater streams and feeds on insects at the surface. It is livebearing and important in evolutionary studies.
A North American minnow known as the greenhead shiner, inhabiting small streams in the southeastern U.S. It feeds on insects and algae. Populations are threatened by habitat loss and water pollution.
Known as the Topeka shiner, it inhabits prairie streams in the central U.S. It is federally endangered due to habitat destruction. It plays an ecological role as a forage species for predators.
A characin from Brazil, inhabiting rivers with moderate flow. It is carnivorous, feeding on fish and aquatic insects. It is locally valued as a game fish.
A plotosid catfish from New Guinea rivers. It is benthic, feeding on worms, insects, and small fishes. It is part of local artisanal fisheries.
A cyprinid from southern Africa, inhabiting rivers with rocky substrates. It feeds on insects and small fish. Its populations have declined due to invasive predators.
A glassfish native to Southeast Asia, living in rivers and swamps. Its transparent body provides camouflage from predators. It feeds on plankton and insects.
A small loricariid catfish endemic to Brazil’s Caatinga region. It inhabits shallow streams, feeding on algae and detritus. Its limited range makes it vulnerable to drought.
A small cyprinid from India, inhabiting streams and rivers with vegetation. It feeds on algae, insects, and detritus. Its restricted distribution makes it vulnerable.
A mormyrid from African rivers, known for weak electric discharges. It feeds on insect larvae and detritus. It contributes to the ecology of turbid river habitats.
A characin from Colombia and Ecuador, inhabiting fast-flowing rivers. It feeds on aquatic insects and algae. Its golden-spotted body makes it attractive in aquaria.
A small characin endemic to Brazil. It inhabits streams and rivers and feeds on zooplankton and insect larvae. It has ecological importance despite its small size.
A plotosid catfish from New Guinea, found in rivers and estuaries. It is benthic and feeds on crustaceans and fish. It supports small-scale fisheries.
A livebearing poeciliid from Hispaniola, inhabiting freshwater streams and lagoons. It feeds on algae and detritus. It is locally vulnerable to pollution and habitat loss.
Found in the southern Caribbean, inhabiting freshwater and brackish habitats. It feeds on algae, detritus, and small invertebrates. It is a hardy species and occasionally kept in aquaria.
A small African mormyrid found in rocky rivers. It uses weak electric signals for orientation and foraging. It feeds on insect larvae and plays a role in benthic food webs.
A goby from Southeast Asia, occurring in estuaries and rivers. It is benthic, feeding on insects and small crustaceans. Its biology is poorly studied.
A characin from Brazil’s Paraíba do Sul basin. It inhabits rivers and streams, feeding on algae, insects, and detritus. It is locally threatened by habitat degradation.
A South American catfish found in rivers and floodplains. It is nocturnal and feeds on insects, crustaceans, and small fish. It is important in local fisheries.
A small characin inhabiting Amazonian rivers. It feeds on plankton, insect larvae, and algae. It is important as a forage species in aquatic food webs.
A blue-eye fish from New Guinea, inhabiting streams and lagoons. It feeds on plankton and insects and is valued in the aquarium trade. Its bright colors make it popular with hobbyists.
Another blue-eye from New Guinea, occurring in swampy lowland habitats. It feeds on insect larvae and plankton. It is small but ecologically significant as a prey item.
A cyprinid endemic to Lebanon, living in rivers and streams. It feeds on invertebrates, algae, and detritus. Its restricted range makes it vulnerable to habitat loss.
A South American catfish inhabiting medium to large rivers. It is predatory, feeding on fish and crustaceans. It plays a role as a mid-level predator in freshwater ecosystems.
A cyprinid from Southeast Asia inhabiting rivers, streams, and lakes. It is a schooling fish that feeds on plankton and insects. Its abundance makes it an important forage fish.
Found in Borneo and nearby islands, this cyprinid prefers clear forest streams. It feeds on plankton and small insects and is locally common. It is popular in the aquarium trade.

A small cyprinid endemic to Lake Victoria, also called “dagaa.” It is one of the most abundant fish in the lake and forms a crucial part of the local fishery. It is dried and traded widely as a staple protein source.
Known as the common smelt, it is native to New Zealand and Australia. It inhabits rivers, lakes, and estuaries, feeding on zooplankton. It is an important forage species for larger fish and birds.
A South American catfish living in rivers and floodplains. It feeds on insects, worms, and fish, and is used in small-scale fisheries. It is ecologically significant as a benthic predator.
A Central American catfish inhabiting rivers and lakes. It is nocturnal and feeds on invertebrates and small fish. It is important in local artisanal fisheries.
A cichlid native to southern Mexico and Guatemala. It inhabits rivers with rocky substrates and displays parental care of eggs and fry. It is valued in the aquarium trade.
A small characin from Panama and Colombia. It lives in rivers and streams, feeding on insects and plankton. It is an important forage species for larger predators.
A cyprinid endemic to Italy, inhabiting rivers and lakes. It feeds on insects, algae, and detritus. Its restricted distribution makes it of conservation concern.
Found in Turkey, this cyprinid inhabits rivers and lakes with moderate flow. It is omnivorous, feeding on algae, plants, and invertebrates. Its restricted range puts it at conservation risk.
A parasitic catfish from the Amazon Basin. It attaches to larger fishes and feeds on their blood and mucus. Its unusual ecology makes it one of the more specialized South American catfishes.
A freshwater goby from Palau, inhabiting clear, fast-flowing streams. It uses fused pelvic fins to cling to rocks in strong currents. It feeds on algae and small invertebrates.
An herbivorous grunter native to northern Australia. It inhabits rivers and floodplain lagoons, grazing on algae and detritus. It is ecologically important for nutrient cycling in freshwater systems.

An Australian freshwater grunter found in the Fitzroy River system. It is herbivorous, scraping algae and detritus from submerged rocks, playing a vital role in nutrient cycling. Its populations are impacted by water extraction and habitat changes.
A cyprinid endemic to Montenegro and Albania, inhabiting clear, fast-flowing streams. It feeds on aquatic invertebrates and algae. Its restricted range and water pollution make it vulnerable.

Distributed in Italy and Switzerland, this cyprinid prefers cool rivers and streams. It is omnivorous, feeding on small invertebrates, algae, and detritus. Populations are sensitive to water pollution and habitat fragmentation.

A cichlid native to Central America, inhabiting rivers with rocky substrates. It is omnivorous, with a diet of algae, invertebrates, and detritus. Known for parental care, it is also a popular aquarium species.

Endemic to Mexico, found in rivers and lagoons with sandy or muddy bottoms. Males are brightly colored during breeding, and the species is known for biparental care. It is valued in aquaculture and aquaria.
A cichlid distributed in Guatemala and Belize, inhabiting clear rivers. It feeds on detritus, algae, and invertebrates. It is hardy and common in the aquarium trade.
A goodeid fish from central Mexico, preferring high-altitude springs and streams. It is livebearing and feeds on algae and insect larvae. It is highly threatened due to habitat loss and pollution.
A large cichlid from Costa Rica and Panama, living in fast-flowing rivers. It is omnivorous, feeding on algae, fruits, and small invertebrates. It is important in local fisheries.
A catfish from South American mountain streams. It lives in fast-flowing habitats and feeds on insect larvae. Its adaptations allow survival in oxygen-rich, cold waters.
A South American stream catfish inhabiting rocky rivers. It preys on insect larvae and detritus. It serves as a bioindicator for clean, well-oxygenated waters.
A loach endemic to Central Asia, inhabiting cold, fast-flowing mountain streams. It feeds on periphyton and benthic invertebrates. Its limited distribution makes it vulnerable to habitat changes.
A South American catfish endemic to Brazil, inhabiting rocky rivers. It feeds on aquatic invertebrates and small fishes. Due to its restricted range, it is considered at conservation risk.
A halfbeak from the Philippines, inhabiting coastal streams and estuaries. It feeds on insects and algae, usually at the water’s surface. It plays a role in linking terrestrial and aquatic food webs.
A cyprinid from southern India, found in rivers and reservoirs. It is omnivorous, feeding on algae, insects, and detritus. It is occasionally used in local fisheries.
A livebearing goodeid fish endemic to Mexico. It inhabits streams with moderate currents and feeds on algae and invertebrates. It is important in conservation programs due to declining populations.

Known as the marbled goodeid, it inhabits rivers and lakes in Mexico. It is livebearing and feeds on algae, detritus, and small invertebrates. It is of conservation concern due to habitat degradation.
A Mexican goodeid fish living in rivers with clear water. It is herbivorous and livebearing, making it important for ecological studies. It is threatened by agricultural runoff and habitat loss.
A cichlid endemic to Mexico, inhabiting rivers with rocky substrates. It feeds on algae, insects, and small fish. It shows strong parental care and is sometimes kept in aquaria.
A darter native to North America, found in rocky streams. It feeds on insect larvae and small invertebrates. Its presence indicates high water quality.
A goby from Sri Lanka, inhabiting clear streams with sandy bottoms. It is benthic, feeding on insect larvae and detritus. It is poorly studied but considered locally important.
A North American bullhead catfish restricted to Georgia. It inhabits rivers and feeds on insects, worms, and small fish. It is considered vulnerable due to its narrow distribution.
A cyprinid from India, inhabiting fast-flowing streams. It grazes on algae using its specialized mouthparts. It is an important grazer in river ecosystems.
A cyprinid fish found in southern India, inhabiting rivers and reservoirs. It feeds on plant matter, detritus, and small invertebrates. It is threatened by overfishing and habitat changes.
A small cyprinid endemic to India, restricted to the Western Ghats. It lives in clear streams and feeds on plankton and insect larvae. Its limited range makes it vulnerable.
A bitterling native to East Asia, inhabiting rivers and lakes. It has a unique spawning strategy, laying eggs inside mussels for protection. It is threatened by habitat modification.
A loach from India, inhabiting rivers and streams with sandy substrates. It feeds on benthic invertebrates. It is poorly studied but locally significant.
Another Indian loach, found in fast-flowing Western Ghats streams. It grazes on algae and invertebrates. It is threatened by deforestation and water pollution.
A cyprinid from Southeast Asia inhabiting rivers and hill streams. It feeds on insects and small crustaceans. It is locally common but threatened by deforestation.
A glassfish from India, living in rivers and estuaries. Its transparent body provides camouflage. It feeds on zooplankton and insect larvae.
A goodeid endemic to Mexico, inhabiting lakes and slow rivers. It is livebearing and feeds on detritus, algae, and small invertebrates. It is under conservation concern.
A cyprinid found in Indian rivers and streams. It feeds on insects and small aquatic organisms. It is threatened by habitat destruction.
A rudd species endemic to the Balkans. It inhabits lakes and rivers, feeding on algae, plants, and small invertebrates. Its populations are declining due to water pollution.
A cichlid from Central America, inhabiting rivers with rocky substrates. It is omnivorous and known for parental care of fry. It is rare in the aquarium trade.

Known as the bloater, this coregonid is native to the Great Lakes of North America. It inhabits deep waters and feeds on zooplankton and benthic invertebrates. Once abundant, it declined due to overfishing and invasive species.
A barbel endemic to Italy, inhabiting rivers and streams. It feeds on algae, invertebrates, and detritus. It is threatened by pollution and invasive species.
Known as the shortnose sturgeon, native to eastern North America. It is anadromous, migrating between rivers and the sea. It is endangered due to overfishing and habitat loss.

The Chinese paddlefish, formerly inhabiting the Yangtze River. It was one of the world’s largest freshwater fishes, feeding on fish and crustaceans. It was declared extinct in the 2000s due to damming and overfishing.
A tilapia species native to East Africa, especially Lake Victoria. It inhabits shallow waters and feeds on algae and plankton. Its populations have been decimated by Nile perch introduction.
A small cyprinid native to Taiwan, inhabiting clear streams. It feeds on plankton and insect larvae. It is highly threatened due to habitat destruction.
A sucker fish from western North America, living in rivers and lakes. It feeds on algae and benthic invertebrates. Its populations are stable but localized.
Known as the longjaw cisco, formerly found in the Great Lakes. It inhabited deep waters and fed on zooplankton. It was declared extinct in the 20th century.
A deepwater cisco native to Lake Michigan, now extinct. It fed on plankton and small invertebrates. Overfishing and invasive species caused its disappearance.
Another extinct cisco from the Great Lakes. It lived in deep waters and was commercially exploited. Invasive species and overfishing drove its extinction.
Known as the Leon Springs pupfish, endemic to Texas. It inhabits desert springs and feeds on algae and small invertebrates. It is critically endangered.
The Pecos pupfish from New Mexico and Texas, inhabiting desert rivers and springs. It feeds on algae and detritus. Hybridization with introduced species threatens its survival.
The Potosí pupfish from Mexico, now extinct. It lived in desert springs, feeding on algae and invertebrates. Habitat drying caused its extinction in the 1990s.
Known as the tidewater goby, endemic to California. It inhabits brackish lagoons and estuaries, feeding on small invertebrates. It is federally endangered due to habitat loss.
A desert fish from New Mexico and Texas, inhabiting springs and streams. It feeds on algae and small invertebrates. It is critically endangered due to water use.
A small minnow endemic to Oregon. It inhabits clear rivers and streams, feeding on insects and algae. Its restricted range makes it vulnerable.
A killifish endemic to Lake Titicaca. It forms a key part of local fisheries, feeding on plankton and invertebrates. It is culturally important to Andean communities.
Known as the Clear Lake splittail, once endemic to California. It inhabited Clear Lake but is now extinct. It fed on plankton and benthic invertebrates.
A rainbowfish from eastern Australia, living in streams and swamps. It is colorful and popular in aquaria. It feeds on insect larvae and algae.
A bitterling from Japan, using mussels for egg deposition. It inhabits rivers and ponds. Habitat destruction has led to serious declines.
A cyprinid from Central Asia, inhabiting rivers and lakes. It feeds on insects and algae. Its populations are stable but locally affected by water regulation.
A minnow from Arizona and New Mexico, inhabiting streams and rivers. It feeds on algae, detritus, and invertebrates. It is vulnerable to water extraction.
The Florida bass, native to the southeastern U.S. It inhabits lakes and rivers and is carnivorous, preying on fish and invertebrates. It is valued as a sport fish.
A silverside from southern South America, found in rivers and lakes. It feeds on plankton and small invertebrates. It is important in local fisheries.
Another silverside from southern Brazil and Uruguay. It inhabits freshwater lagoons and estuaries. It is a key species in artisanal fisheries.
